Implement an extensible ID scheme for the LmdbStore that also allows to embed values into IDs.

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Use a binary encoding for IDs that allows to represent the value type, if the value itself is embedded within the id and the embedded value itself.

> @kenwenzel You know you have committer rights now so you don't have to use your fork anymore.

Thank you for the.hint. Do you prefer the creation of branches in this repo rather than using a/my fork?
The failing integration tests: It's a test that is marked as disabled, but has somehow started to run again. Not sure how that happened.

> > @kenwenzel You know you have committer rights now so you don't have to use your fork anymore.
> 
> 
> 
> Thank you for the.hint. Do you prefer the creation of branches in this repo rather than using a/my fork?

Would be nice if you used the RDF4J repo. Nice thing is that it allows others to work on your branch, though that's probably not going to happen very often.
@hmottestad Should I merge this on my own?

I prefer if you request a code review. It doesn't have to be me doing the code review, can also be someone else who is active on the project, at the moment it's mostly Jerven who is active. You can request a review from either one of us, and if you get an "approval" then feel free to merge it. 

If you don't get a response to your review request ping me and if you still don't hear anything after a few more days then feel free to do a "self review" and merge. Unless you feel that your changes are very big, a fundamental change or you have a funky solution to something that you want feedback on.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4952 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Introduce `FedXConfig` option overrides for `FedXRepositoryConfig` so that repo templates can also access options which previously were only available programmatically.

We've raised the PR against the `main` branch because from our understanding it's not clear yet when v5.0.0 will be released and we'd be looking to use this feature in production ourselves. Looking at what's changed between 4 latest & 5 (against the files affected by this change) I think it should be trivial to port.

----

Note: Integration test pipeline has failed due to an unrelated reason:
> compliance/rio/src/test/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/rio/n3/N3ParserTest.java:28 | Expected '.', found '3' [line 2]
I've set it to rerun the integration test. I've not seen this test being flaky before, but maybe it is.
It's not an issue with your code. It's a test that is marked as disabled, but has somehow started to run again. Not sure how that happened.
@vtermanis did you have a chance to look at the above feedback? I think it would be ready with a minimal technical change of moving some pieces of code to protected methods.

@aschwarte10  - sorry about the delay, we've been busy. I will update the PR based your recommendations. Thank you for the initial review.
Follow up Q: It occurred to me that it'll be useful to us to also be able to tweak the join block size and maybe the worker thread counts. To that effect: Is it worth exposing **all** (apart from from TaskWrapper) options? Are there any which you don't think people should touch?
I've added the remaining conf options: f72c49a030b1f244

> In addition, users would benefit from a small documentation adjustment of https://rdf4j.org/documentation/programming/federation/#fedx-configuration (stating with a small example that settings can be added in the repository configuration).

I've added that in a separate commit - see what you think.
@aschwarte10 I've created a CQ for the license issue, but you don't need to wait for that before you merge this PR.

> Sorry for the delay

No, problem. Thanks for the review!

comments: Hm... need to check why the build fails...

Looks good in general. There are some test failures, I triggered the CI again to see if the tests still fail.

Any chance you could create a test that writes -> parses -> writes to see if the output stays the same?

@hmottestad I have added two additional tests that check to which extend the format is preserved in a round trip. While the data is isomorphic, the actual serialization is different.

E.g. if I parse this:

```
prefix server-news: <news:comp.infosystems.www.servers.> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
server-news:unix rdfs:label "News on Unix" .
server-news:windows rdfs:label "News on Windows" .
```

and serialize it out again, it comes out as:

```
@prefix server-news: <news:comp.infosystems.www.servers.> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
<news:comp.infosystems.www.servers.unix> rdfs:label "News on Unix" .
<news:comp.infosystems.www.servers.windows> rdfs:label "News on Windows" .
```

That seems to be because the `AbstractRDFParser` fails to consider the namespace declarations from the Turtle when generating the IRI instances.

While I think that should also be fixed, it seems to me a) worth a new issue, b) a larger change and for me personally, I'm currently more interested in the serialization than in the parsing - so I'd defer that.

So if we decide to keep these tests, at least the string comparison on the Turtle serialization would need to be removed or commented out until the parser properly respects the prefix declarations in the source file.

I have added a new issue for this: https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/issues/4929

So a the reason why `testPerformance(org.eclipse.rdf4j.rio.rdfxml.RDFXMLPrettyWriterBackgroundTest)` fails the is that the RDFXML writer actually respects prefix/namespace/localname delarations in IRIs, but because the test actually declares a IRI with an invalid localname, the test breaks due to the change that `SImpleIRI` now actually preserves this properly.

**org.eclipse.rdf4j.rio.RDFWriterTest.RDFWriterTest(RDFWriterFactory, RDFParserFactory)**
```
exNs = "http://example.org/";
uri5 = vf.createIRI(exNs, "uri5/you");
```

Before the improvement to `SimpleIRI` to properly preserve namespace and localname, this was serialized as
```
<you xmlns="http://example.org/uri5/" rdf:about="http://example.org/49/a111"/>
```

Now, this comes out as

```
<ex:uri5/you rdf:about="http://example.org/49/a111"/>
```

In the Turtle module, I check now if using a prefixed version would create an invalid Turtle syntax and if this is the case, I use the pointy-brackets notation.

I guess RDFXML (and maybe other formats) would need a similar change as well...

@hmottestad Ok, I added a check into the `RDFXMLPrettyWriter` to prevent illegal local names from being written - if such a name is encountered, the system will instead try to generate a valid local name.

I am not sure if it is desirable to preserve the initial namespace-localname-split in SimpleIRI. How does this influence the behavior of the generic IRI interface? 
If the IRI is stored in NativeStore or LmdbStore in between then the original components will be lost.

@kenwenzel for my use-case, I do not really care if prefixed and namespaces are always preserved. But what I care for is that if I build a model in which I explicitly declare prefixes/namespaces and also if I create IRIs with explicit namespaces, then this should be respected.

In general, I would think it would be sensible to also respect declared namespaces and prefixes when reading IRIs from a store into a model and then serializing them into a file. If the model has prefix declarations, then it would be sensible to try matching the IRI against these prefixes and then use the best match. But this would be slower then just doing an IRI namespace lookup in the prefix table, so I opted for the moment against implementing that.
@hmottestad how can we proceed here?
@reckart this fix here and the other fix you've contributed are released in 4.3.11.
Wow, a release specifically with my contributions :) That is a great easter present üëç Thanks.
commit_messages: GH-4921 Turtle writer does not respect namespaces in IRIs (#4922)

comments:
@JervenBolleman I've run into a more general issue with your rewrite of the `SPARQLQueryComplianceTest` class et al. because the JUnit 5 `@TestFactory` annotation doesn't work very well with the `@TempDir` annotation. In fact `@TestFactory` doesn't work well with any of the lifecycle annotations, including before each. Essentially the combination of `@TestFactory` and `@TempDir` means that we use the same temporary directory for all the tests in a class, instead of a new sail and repository with a new temporary directory for each and every test.

This issue has been masked by the test code catching exceptions. Pretty much none of the NativeStore tests have been running. I managed to get the NativeStore tests working now, but the LmdbStore doesn't seem so happy about being continuously re-instantiated on top of the directory for an existing LmdbStore. @kenwenzel maybe you could take a look at why the LmdbStore gets upset after a while when being shutdown and then recreated on the same directory. You should be able to reproduce the issues by running `LmdbPARQL11UpdateComplianceTest`.

Oh no, I am so sorry for this! I ran into this in the RepositorySPARQLComplianceTestSuite and didn't think to see where else the same problem could have hidden. I am going to quickly see if the same fix can apply here.

"Aldri s√• galt at det ikke er godt for noe" - Norwegian way to say that even when bad things happen they still bring something good. The ExtensibleStore test failing led to discovering the issue with the tests here, and that led to discovering the issue with the LmdbStore :)

Maybe a quick fix is to add a File or Path param to the creeateRepo method and manually handle the creating and deletion of temporary directories.

Another approach would be to try to use the ParamaterizedTest annotation with the method source option. I do this with the ShaclSail where I read the directory structure to generate the tests at runtime.

It's still really nice to be able to run just a single test from IntelliJ though! Instead of always having to run every single one like I had to before.

I tried to create a dir per dynamic test. Still have the failing extensiblestore test. Native and Lmdb tests seem to run?
The code is in [pull:4888](https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/pull/4888)

Yeah, I think the ExtensibleStore failure is unrelated. It uses a ConcurrentHashMap as the main data structure when running the tests, so maybe there are some changes to that class in jdk 21 that is causing the issue. Not sure what it could be, and it's particularly annoying that I can't reproduce it in IntelliJ.

I found out that the issue with the ExtensibleStore was that it was sometimes not returning all the named contexts/graphs. It would stop the iterator on the first default graph (null). So a slight difference in the ordering of statements when run with JDK 21 through Maven was what was triggering the bug.
@hmottestad I could imagine that something is not correctly closed when unsing the LmdbStore. Have you checked that everything gets closed after running the tests?
From what I could see everything is closed correctly, but I haven't done anything more than look over the code.

Is the store instantiated with an empty directory or are there any artifacts left from the previous run?
It might also be the case that the store is not correctly closed due to some issue like
https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/issues/4806

I'll try to take a look within the next days.

> Is the store instantiated with an empty directory or are there any artifacts left from the previous run?
> 
> It might also be the case that the store is not correctly closed due to some issue like
> 
> https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/issues/4806
> 
> 
> 
> I'll try to take a look within the next days.

You can checkout this commit here: 5d825520e1c268222d6cb0163724c26ffa94f539

The issues occurs when the store is shutdown() and then recreated with the same directory. It doesn't happen immediately but after ~6 times.

> > Is the store instantiated with an empty directory or are there any artifacts left from the previous run?
> > It might also be the case that the store is not correctly closed due to some issue like
> > #4806
> > I'll try to take a look within the next days.
> 
> You can checkout this commit here: [5d82552](https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/commit/5d825520e1c268222d6cb0163724c26ffa94f539)
> 
> The issues occurs when the store is shutdown() and then recreated with the same directory. It doesn't happen immediately but after ~6 times.

@hmottestad I nailed this down to an issue with the LMDB ValueStore and its recycling of IDs. I hope that I can fix this within the next days.

@JervenBolleman Any chance you could take a look at this PR? I made a test, but I didn't make a benchmark query yet. The benchmark run I did shows that there at least doesn't seem to be any performance degradation.

@JervenBolleman I actually found out that the QueryJoinOptimizer is able to optimise sub-selects, but not if there are multiple sub-selects or if there are any BIND clauses anywhere. I've made two benchmarks that will make sure that we don't break that optimisation later.

body:
The current implementation of the algorithm for the hierachical JSON-LD output changes references of the triples stored in `List`s and keeps adding these references to the output. This can leed to infinite loops when traversing the result. Making copies of the contained lists avoids this.


GitHub issue resolved: #4833

commit_messages:
GH-4833: Copy triple structures to avoid infinite loops

The current implementation of the algorithm for the hierachical JSON-LD
output changes references of the triples stored in `List`s and keeps
adding these references to the output. This can leed to infinite loops
when traversing the result. Making copies of the contained lists avoids
this.

body:
This commit provides a unit test that reproduces a deadlock scenario. The issue is somewhere caused in the join with NUnion, and specifically the union parts having relevant statements in multiple sources.

Note that the dataset is really small (42 triples, 40 relevant ones contributing to the result)


For some details and explanation please refer to my comment in the issue at https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/issues/4785#issuecomment-1786847011

comments:
Thanks for this fix @domkun I think it's related to the default interface method implementation. 

For the next major version of RDF4J we are simplifying the Iteration and CloseableIteration interfaces by removing the Iteration interface and making everything use just the CloseableIteration interface. This makes me think that this bug hopefully doesn't exist in RDF4J 5.0.0-M2 (our latests milestone build). 

Any chance you could test 5.0.0-M2 to see if the bug still exists or not. If it's not present in 5.0.0-M2 then I'm fine with merging your PR as is, without a need for a test.
Hi @hmottestad , you are right, the bug does not exist in version 5.0.0-M2, just checked it. Running the reproducer from the issue against 5.0.0-M2 works without a problem.

comments: @abrokenjester @kenwenzel I'm working on support merge join. The first step is to add support for the sail to return ordered statements. I would really appreciate some feedback on how to make my changes as consistent as possible with the existing interfaces. Any suggestions on naming is also very welcome.

Multi variable joins might be problematic:

```
 ?a a ?b.
 ?a ex:type ?b.
```
@hmottestad I can offer to add support for ordered indexes to LmdbStore. Do you already have any performance figures?

> @hmottestad I can offer to add support for ordered indexes to LmdbStore. Do you already have any performance figures?

This would be really awesome. I've tagged you above in a comment to show what needs to be implemented. That should hopefully be all that is needed. One thing I'm not certain about is transaction isolation, so it might be best to test it out with IsolationLevels.NONE. There is also some work left to be done on the DualUnionIteration, let me know if you run into the UnsupportedOperationException in that class.

I haven't made any benchmarks, mostly because I've only implemented this in the ExtensibleStore with a backing data structure that sorts the data for each request.  That is just so I can test things out locally. The end goal is for https://github.com/the-qa-company/qEndpoint to use it for analytical queries. They have a really innovative product that uses HDT for storing the data on disk and can work with massive datasets using very little memory.

The queries that we want to support are ones that would anyway need to read most of the data from a range query on the index.

For instance:
```
select (count(?a) as ?count) where {
    ?a a foaf:Person; # using a OPSC index
       foaf:age ?age. # using a PSOC index
}
```

If you want to see if the query planner chooses merge join you can use the query explanation:

```
Explanation explain = connection
    .prepareTupleQuery(query)
    .explain(Explanation.Level.Executed);
System.out.println(explain);
```

And you should see `Join (InnerMergeJoinIterator)` in the query explanation. 

Here is an example for a completely different query:
```
Projection (resultSizeActual=5)
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïê ProjectionElemList
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "s"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "o"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "o2"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "s2"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "o3"
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïê Join (JoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=5)
   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Join (InnerMergeJoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=5) [left]
   ‚îÇ  ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïê Join (InnerMergeJoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=5) [left]
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë  ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ StatementPattern [statementOrder: S]  (costEstimate=0, resultSizeEstimate=0, resultSizeActual=5) [left]
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë  ‚îÇ     s: Var (name=s)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë  ‚îÇ     p: Var (name=_const_9285ccfc_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë  ‚îÇ     o: Var (name=o)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë  ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ StatementPattern [statementOrder: S]  (costEstimate=0, resultSizeEstimate=0, resultSizeActual=14) [right]
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë        s: Var (name=s)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë        p: Var (name=_const_44b0da67_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïë        o: Var (name=o2)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïê StatementPattern [statementOrder: S]  (costEstimate=0, resultSizeEstimate=0, resultSizeActual=14) [right]
   ‚îÇ        s: Var (name=s)
   ‚îÇ        p: Var (name=_const_531c5f7d_uri, value=http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/knows, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ        o: Var (name=s2)
   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ StatementPattern (costEstimate=0, resultSizeEstimate=0, resultSizeActual=5) [right]
         s: Var (name=s2)
         p: Var (name=_const_44b0da67_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#comment, anonymous)
         o: Var (name=o3)
```

This all gives me an idea for making the query explanation smarter by including what index is being used and a recommendation for the most optimal index so the user can configure the best indexes for their particular queries.

@hmottestad Probably the merge join will show its strength when the IO performance degrades due to memory mapping and/or slow storage systems. This should be the case if the databases grow larger than RAM.
@kenwenzel collaborating on merge join would be a lot simpler if you were a committer. Would you be interested in me nominating you?

> @kenwenzel collaborating on merge join would be a lot simpler if you were a committer. Would you be interested in me nominating you?

I can't make guarantees regarding contributions but I don't want to refuse the offer a second time (Jeen already asked a while ago). So yes and thank you for asking.
@hmottestad I was asked by the team (@D063520) behind [the qEndpoint](https://github.com/the-qa-company/qEndpoint/) to help with implementing merge joins :) and I see you are already working on it.

> @hmottestad I was asked by the team (@D063520) behind [the qEndpoint](https://github.com/the-qa-company/qEndpoint/) to help with implementing merge joins :) and I see you are already working on it.

I think it is wonderful you/the qa company are sponsoring this feature and @hmottestad is much better at this kind of work then I am :) win win all round.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4784 #4790 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

This is mainly an issue with the MemoryStore, but has been detected when using the ShaclSail since it uses memory stores for tracking the changes in a transaction.

When one connection holds the MemorySailStore `txnLockManager` then another thread can get stuck waiting for the same lock if both threads are forcefully closed. Two issues are causing this, the first is that the `txnLockManager` can't be forcefully unlocked by another thread, the second is that the `txnLockManager` is being locked without support for interruptions.

The fix is to track the owner thread of the connection and interrupt that thread. Since connections shouldn't be shared between threads we can assume that the thread that created the connection is the owner.

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

comments: @abrokenjester Could you take a look at this scoping issue? @fkleedorfer accidentally ran into it and I have managed to make some tests to reproduce the issue. I had initially tracked it back to https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/issues/3601 and reverting the changes to the FilterIterator seemed to fix the issue. However while I was working on the tests to reproduce it locally I managed to accidentally create yet another scoping scenario that was not solved by simply reverting the FilterIterator.

@hmottestad I am looking into this issue. And I was investigating testScope1 and I am wondering about the query plan. 
The surprising part extracted?

```
Filter (new scope) (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=9, resultSizeActual=4) [right]
            ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïê Compare (!=) <!-- Not a in operator.
            ‚ïë     Var (name=type, value=http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/Person) <!-- Why do we have a value set?
            ‚ïë     ValueConstant (value=http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/NotPerson)
            ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïê StatementPattern (resultSizeEstimate=9, resultSizeActual=4)
                  s: Var (name=person)
                  p: Var (name=_const_8d89de74_uri, value=http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/age, anonymous)
                  o: Var (name=age)
```
Could it be an optimizer bug?  as the compare is seen to have a constant value by the time it gets to the filter operation?

If I remove the SameTermFilterOptimizer from the flow then the test passes. 
Looking into it the SameTermFilterOptimizer sets the type value to a constant where it should not. Looks like that optimizer does not take into account a scope change.
Ok, it's a double bug :( one indeed in the SameTermFilterOptimizer that should stop messing with variables out of scope. The other with filtering variables that are not in scope.
Thanks for figuring this out @JervenBolleman !
@hmottestad looks like the original logic was sufficient.
@JervenBolleman great work! You want to clean up the commented out code and then merge this?

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4401 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

- remove experimental status of CONFIG vocabulary
- switch back to use of new vocabulary as the default (using legacy vocab as a fallback) 
- added support for fully converting existing config files
- added test coverage for working with legacy config files
- added an env var feature flag to optionally switch back to legacy vocabulary.
- added release/upgrade notes

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [x] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [x] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [x] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [x] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [x] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments: @hmottestad I'm getting a build failure in the osgi-runtime - I seem to recall you recently had a similar issue?
Looks like there was a fix for the osgi issue on main which is not yet synced onto the develop branch. Doing a manual branch sync.
Doing a small fix in the package-assembly github action - see https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/pull/4746

I'm having a bit of second thoughts about changing up the vocabulary. I know that we don't own the domain names anymore, but that doesn't really affect our code. 

I had put some effort into making the new and old vocabulary work together in 4.3, but it still managed to break the sail templates used in the workbench. And we don't have a single test for the workbench as far as I can tell. It's a bit worrying that we will have to do a lot of manual verification and hope we've thought of everything. And that also goes for everyone building on top of RDF4J, for instance GraphDB and Halyard.

I'm planning to run some further manual tests and report those here. I've also,  as part of this PR, significantly improved test coverage and added better support for mixed vocab usage as well as the choice to stick completely with legacy vocab for now (though I don't recommend that). 

Workbench test coverage is a problem,  but not to the extent that I want to cancel this improvement.  The breakage in 4.3 was unfortunate but those problems have been addressed,  and this time we are doing this as part of a major release.

# Test Notes

## default behavior

- [x] Server and Workbench start correctly
- [x] new repository gets created with new vocabulary config and is usable 
- [x] legacy config gets read correctly and converted

## useLegacyConfig flag enabled

- [x]  Server and Workbench start correctly
- [x] new repository gets created with legacy vocabulary config and is usable 
- [x] legacy config gets read correctly and is _not_ converted

Given the above and the test results I shared, could I get another review over this? If there's additional things you'd like to see tested (but don't have the time to do yourself) let me know and I can take a look at it over the weekend. If not, I would consider this done and we can merge it into develop.
I'll try to find some time to look it over again.

Hello @JervenBolleman  üòÉ 

I have noticed that in your recent commit you referenced Issue [GH-4656](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4656) as the problem being addressed. However, after reviewing the commit and the issue description, it seems that the referenced issue might have been accidentally mentioned. 

If I understand correctly, this should fix issue [4646](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4646)?

@JervenBolleman , with this fix, I get the same error with a bit more detail in the error message:

`java.lang.AssertionError: We don't actually support adding a binding. asil : "QM"
        at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.ArrayBindingSet.addBinding(ArrayBindingSet.java:336)
        at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.MutableBindingSet.addBinding(MutableBindingSet.java:30)
        at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.impl.evaluationsteps.BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep$1.getNextElement(BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep.java:67)
        at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.impl.evaluationsteps.BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep$1.getNextElement(BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep.java:47)
        at org.eclipse.rdf4j.common.iteration.LookAheadIteration.lookAhead(LookAheadIteration.java:80)
...`

> @JervenBolleman , with this fix, I get the same error with a bit more detail in the error message:
> 
> `java.lang.AssertionError: We don't actually support adding a binding. asil : "QM" at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.ArrayBindingSet.addBinding(ArrayBindingSet.java:336) at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.MutableBindingSet.addBinding(MutableBindingSet.java:30) at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.impl.evaluationsteps.BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep$1.getNextElement(BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep.java:67) at org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.impl.evaluationsteps.BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep$1.getNextElement(BindingSetAssignmentQueryEvaluationStep.java:47) at org.eclipse.rdf4j.common.iteration.LookAheadIteration.lookAhead(LookAheadIteration.java:80) ...`

I am getting the same error, can we maybe consider reverting [this element in getNextElement](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/4d181d675bfbf46e6961c3a7be836eb99a250c4e/core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/iterator/HashJoinIteration.java#L194) to [how it was in 3.7.7](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/b11b4a5061a9313d7a777edca3a9c471a15508e8/core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/iterator/HashJoinIteration.java#L161) ?

Sorry but I am on vacation and I couldn't properly fix it before heading
out without laptop.

Reverting the next element method just leaves the problem in place for
later in the evaluation.

The issue is unexpected variables being added to the query evaluation. This
should be fixed consistently or it could pop up in the future again
elsewhere.

comments: I think the code is fine as bug fix. On the other hand perhaps it is a good idea to discuss serialization for v5 and later.

> I think the code is fine as bug fix. On the other hand perhaps it is a good idea to discuss serialization for v5 and later.

I would prefer to drop it, but I did try to quickly serialise the objects to json using Gson which failed due to some cycles in the abstract query tree. Having some way of persisting the abstract query tree would be very useful if we want to cache query plans. I would also like to be able to transfer the query plans from the server to the client for debugging query performance issues.

GitHub issue resolved: #4622 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

 - switch to RDF4J Binary RDF since this format doesn't rename blank node IDs
 - add parser config option to preserve blank node IDs
 - add test

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

----

comments:
> It all looks technically correct to me, but I'm puzzled by why you'd need blank node preservation here in the first place.
> 
> It's normally something that we only use in _very_ specific internal client-server comms use cases (e.g. in supporting remote transactions). I don't think we ever use it (or recommend using it) for somehow allowing a _user_ to reference a bnode by id remotely.
> 
> Also: we tend to use RDF Binary everywhere else to support this: why choose RDF/JSON in this case?

I haven't tried using RDF Binary. I'll test it out.

The reason I need to preserve blank node identifiers is that this is a transfer of the validation exception from the server to the client. The user would then typically want to find out more about what went wrong by retrieving the full shape from the server. It's common practice to use blank nodes for PropertyShape(s), so that's why we need to preserve the blank node identifiers.

### TODO

- [ ] Add test to make sure the client still works with the old server

I think that this should be split into two branches. One with a simple fix that just changes out the format to binary, and a second that changes things up a bit by using the http body. The second branch should also bump the protocol version and target the develop branch.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4610 

Instead of registering to the root phaser, we need to register to the current phaser. Otherwise we may reach the limit of 65535 for large joins.

Note that in ControlledWorkerJoin and ControlledWorkerLeftJoin this was done correctly.

comments:
Unfortunately I cannot serve with a proper unit test. I had some environment (derived from the issue description) where I had the exception occurring (with the help of local debug tweaking). The issue very much depends on the concurrency. With this fix it is gone

However, I am convinced that this is the fix for the issue, especially when comparing to `ControlledWorkerJoin` and `ControlledWorkerLeftJoin`, see also the original PR https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3108/files#diff-13164a6c512de096d5d4ce745086d18f73ae0fc12610dff908d4491aaac16387

GitHub issue resolved: #4603 #4252

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Upgrades JavaEE/JakartaEE dependencies to version 8 using the Jakarta dependencies managed by the Jakarta EE 8 BOM. Jetty also needs to be upgraded to version 10 to be compatible with JavaEE/JakartaEE, and is also included in this PR.

----

comments:
> I'm not sure what the implications of the jetty issue is. Does it mean that we are shipping with one version in one part of our code and another version somewhere else?

If this is merged and released, we would use Jetty 9 in the Solr compliance module and Jetty 10 in the other modules. I am assuming a very little percentage of our users are actually using the compliance modules, as it appears to be a mostly internal module containing tests. But please correct me if I am wrong.

If we need to use Jetty 9 in the Solr compliance module, wouldn't our users run into issues if they rely on the Solr module (not compliance) together with another module? Would they end up with a having to exclude Jetty 10 to get Solr working?

> If we need to use Jetty 9 in the Solr compliance module, wouldn't our users run into issues if they rely on the Solr module (not compliance) together with another module? Would they end up with a having to exclude Jetty 10 to get Solr working?

I think you are right that this might be an issue. The embedded Solr pulls in Jetty dependencies. I thought it was just test dependencies, but sadly not. Any suggestions for a workaround? Doing everything in one PR does not seem right to me.

Probably need to update Solr, unfortunately. Which entails updating Lucene and probably Elasticsearch. 

I think it's worth double checking how jetty impacts our use of Solr. I assume that our Solr code is just client stuff and that the server stuff is only used for the embedded Solr during testing. Maybe the client code doesn't depend so heavily on Jetty?

Updating the elasticsearch stuff is a true pain due to their licensing, multiple breaking changes and them changing up their client every few months.

GitHub issue resolved: #4511 #4468 #4608 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

We can assume that there is only one thread that can remove statements from the statement list, because there is only 1 cleanup thread in the MemorySailStore. That means we can remove the StampedLock and instead change to being 100% lock free!

I also ended up doing a bit of a rewrite of parts of the code and also fixing a bug I hadn't noticed before.

A lot of time was spent on trying to create a decent test. That test made me discover the bug when the code checks if the write was lost due to the array growing.

@JervenBolleman I'll try to take at look at this as soon as I can.
@hmottestad I am rebasing this so that you don't need to deal with the mergeconflicts.

> @hmottestad I am rebasing this so that you don't need to deal with the mergeconflicts.

Thanks!

@hmottestad the verify/integration-tests stage passes on my laptop. 

However, it does fail on my desktop with the same error as given by the github action :(

@kenwenzel would you mind having a look at this failure. The tests pass for native and memory on all my systems. However, on my desktop and the github action I have strange errors. One difference is that my laptop is fedora while desktop and github action are ubuntu based.

> @kenwenzel would you mind having a look at this failure. The tests pass for native and memory on all my systems. However, on my desktop and the github action I have strange errors. One difference is that my laptop is fedora while desktop and github action are ubuntu based.

Hi @JervenBolleman,

the NPEs are due to lazy values. Maybe the hash code function tries to initialize these values after the store has already been closed.
I've improved the handling of lazy values in this commit:
https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/commit/9b0622a4224587dfc539e9c5ca948f29d1461b4c

This should ensure that values do not leave the SAIL in an uninitialized state.
It may be the case that I've overseen something.
@kenwenzel @hmottestad I found that part of the reason is that these tests now run concurrently and where sharing state. I fixed just this and will push a new commit.
This is pretty sweet! I can debug a single test in IntelliJ!
@hmottestad  sorry for the force push to undo the merge commit :(

I believe that the missing annotation was not the problem. For me other
classes with eclipse it works with just the annotation on the super super
class. I am going to make sure they ran in the logs to be sure.

comments:
Exceptions to japicmp:
 - compliance
 - tools/runtime-osgi
 - tools/server
 - tools/workbench

These are all primarily disabled because japicmp complained that the jar file wasn't available. The compliance and workbench code I agree should not have strict backwards compatibility requirements, osgi should also be fine since it's just a wrapper to enable osgi. The server module, on the other hand, should probably be stricter wrt. backwards compatibility...but then we would need to figure out why japicmp is complaining about the missing jar file.

comments:
Well spotted @naturzukunft I had no idea it would be legal to have more than one  default-graph-uri parameter! But it makes sense as this is an override of the FROM concept and that allows multiple ones.

I think this is fine to go into 5 without further ado, as it is on a method with a limited scope for overriding.

> Well spotted @naturzukunft I had no idea it would be legal to have more than one default-graph-uri parameter! But it makes sense as this is an override of the FROM concept and that allows multiple ones.
> 
> I think this is fine to go into 5 without further ado, as it is on a method with a limited scope for overriding.

That's fine by me too!

At the moment the PR is targeted at the main branch, but if we target it at the develop branch then it will end up in RDF4J 5.0.0.

> > Well spotted @naturzukunft I had no idea it would be legal to have more than one default-graph-uri parameter! But it makes sense as this is an override of the FROM concept and that allows multiple ones.
> > I think this is fine to go into 5 without further ado, as it is on a method with a limited scope for overriding.
> 
> That's fine by me too!
> 
> At the moment the PR is targeted at the main branch, but if we target it at the develop branch then it will end up in RDF4J 5.0.0.

i would prefere to have it in an earlier version!
What are the next steps here ?

I would like to here @abrokenjester opinion on this. I don't think we have ever released a patch version with new interface methods before, even with default implementations. 

This isn't so much a new feature as it is a fix for an oversight in the original code. So it feels more like a bug fix than anything.
I'm planning a milestone build of RDF4J 5.0 and I think it would be good to include this PR in that build.

> I'm planning a milestone build of RDF4J 5.0 and I think it would be good to include this PR in that build.

@hmottestad  when will the milestone build be ready ?
Hopefully within the next week or two.

GitHub issue resolved: #4556 

When creating federation sub-queries from intermediate bindings sets, we need to make sure to properly escape single quotes in literal string.

Example literal: "'A quoted literal'"

When not escaping such single quotes, query parsing fails.

Issue is covered by an integration unit test.

Perfomance looks a lot better now. The ¬± is a bit big. Would be better if the ¬± was somewhere around 10%.

Overall though this is very impressive @kenwenzel !
@hmottestad I had to add some more logic to correctly close changesets under all circumstances.
@hmottestad The Changeset code feels really ugly. Do you see any chance to get rid of `shallowClone`?
@hmottestad What are our next steps regarding this issue?

I need to take a good look at the code and test it out for myself. I also need to take a look at some benchmarks to see how your changes to the Changeset impact serializable transactions. I am fairly limited on time at the moment though, but i'll do my best.

I'm able to reproduce a scenario where a closed Changeset is still used. On my machine I can reproduce it by debugging `org.eclipse.rdf4j.sail.shacl.MultithreadedNativeStoreIT` in `testLotsOfValidationFailuresReadUncommitted()`. Here is where the closed Changeset is still in use: I added some stack traces and found out that the Changeset was closed here: I haven't dug any further than this really.
@hmottestad Thank you for your support :-). I'll try to take a look within the next days. The best would be to get rid of shallowClone completely but I am not sure if this is possible.

I think I introduced shallowClone so that I could optimise the close method. Without shallowClone() a Changeset will be used after it has been closed, which really shouldn't be the case anyway. 

You could split out the performance stuff into its own branch/PR and then focus on the close() stuff separately. I still think it's hard to trace down all the places where the Changeset should/shouldn't be closed and that's it's easier to call it best effort and instead use a Java 9 Cleaner (or preferably our own ConcurrentCleaner) to close any overflow model that doesn't get closed correctly by the Changeset.

This is a phenomenal change! I have been experiencing the issue with that as well.

Great work @kenwenzel, I will be watching this PR.
@hmottestad Should we continue working on this?

> @hmottestad Should we continue working on this?

Yeah sure. I've been testing out some other fixes here: https://github.com/eclipse-rdf4j/rdf4j/pull/4974

A few reverts regarding pom changes.


GitHub issue resolved: #4544 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Just seeing what openrewrite does regarding junit4 to junit5, as well as what they consider best practice.

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

comments: The diff is huge! Would it be possible to split this change - to make it reviewable? Most of the changes seem to be related to improving Java access modifiers.

I have been experimenting with openrewrite to see if I can make it not do this public access removal but have not yet succeeded.

Converting it to draft in the meantime, looks like it will be easier to rerun the rewrite than do the rebase.

using 

mvn -U org.openrewrite.maven:rewrite-maven-plugin:run \
  -Drewrite.recipeArtifactCoordinates=org.openrewrite.recipe:rewrite-testing-frameworks:RELEASE \
  -Drewrite.activeRecipes=org.openrewrite.java.testing.junit5.AddMissingNested

and to check the diferences in java code.
```
git diff -- ../$(git status --porcelain|grep '^ M'|head -n 1|cut -b 4-)
```
if there is public to package method changes undo these with
```
sed -i -e 's|\tvoid |\tpublic void |g' ../$(git status --porcelain|grep '^ M'|head -n 1|cut -b 4-)
# check nothing else changed
git diff -- ../$(git status --porcelain|grep '^ M'|head -n 1|cut -b 4-)
```
then add to the commit
```
git add -- ../$(git status --porcelain|grep '^ M'|head -n 1|cut -b 4-)
```
@erikgb I think it is best to wait with this until #4592 is merged as it kinda depends on that working nicely first. But thanks for already having  a look.

comments:
@abrokenjester I was testing 4.3.0-SNAPSHOT with GraphDB and found out that it uses the config models directly and crashes because it assumes that the deprecated predicates are still in use. Fixing this is kinda fiddly since we need to assume that users can use both the new and deprecated vocabularies for both reading and updating.

In 5.0.0 we can drop support for those who read/manipulate the models directly by changing back to only using the new vocabularies when writing to the model.

> @abrokenjester I was testing 4.3.0-SNAPSHOT with GraphDB and found out that it uses the config models directly and crashes because it assumes that the deprecated predicates are still in use. Fixing this is kinda fiddly since we need to assume that users can use both the new and deprecated vocabularies for both reading and updating.

Isn't the Configurations util a big help for that? They'd basically just need to use those same methods when reading a config model to allow both old and new config files to co-exist.

> > @abrokenjester I was testing 4.3.0-SNAPSHOT with GraphDB and found out that it uses the config models directly and crashes because it assumes that the deprecated predicates are still in use. Fixing this is kinda fiddly since we need to assume that users can use both the new and deprecated vocabularies for both reading and updating.
> 
> Isn't the Configurations util a big help for that? They'd basically just need to use those same methods when reading a config model to allow both old and new config files to co-exist.

It'll definitely help once I get around to migrating to the new vocabulary. At the moment though I consider it a breaking change that it's not possible to upgrade to 4.3.0 unless that change is used consistently throughout the code.

A completely different alternative would be to provide the new vocabulary and Configurations util in 4.3.0, but only start using it in 5.0.0. 

We would still use the Configurations util when reading the config model to support those who want to start migrating now, but we would only write using the current (legacy) vocabulary.
I should really have gotten more involved when this was still in the PR phase, but I'm not sure I would have seen the issues that I've discovered now.

You're completely right of course that if this breaks existing apps, then we have to rethink it. I think the main thing for me is that I still don't fully understand how this is a breaking change though: any Config class we have is set up to read either old or new properties (so it can deal with legacy data as well as new vocabulary), and the methods that write these configs to file have all been fixed to consistently produce new vocabulary. Can you give a code example of how this is used in existing code (in either GraphDB or somewhere else) that would break with this setup? I must be overlooking some obvious use case.

Here is one place where there is an issue in GraphDB: I don't know what this code does, or why it needs to use the vocabulary directly. I don't see anything particularly wrong with this code though. It assumes that the model uses the current (deprecated) vocabulary and fails now that we only use the new vocabulary.

That looks like it might be from a config class in GraphDB itself? Just like our own config classes have a parse method.

If we stuck with the current approach, this code would need to change to use the Configurations fallback method we are currently using ourselves, or something better/easier to use.

The question is: do we consider this sufficiently a breaking change to roll it back, or to introduce something that leaves us with ugly config files that duplicate info? Or can we consider this sufficiently niche that providing some upgrade notes to adapt such cases is good enough?

Fwiw if we decide it should be rolled back I'd be in favour of just completely removing from 4.3, and adding to the 5.0 branch instead.

It's a kind of breaking change that is really hard to debug because it ends up causing a strange exception way down the line with no indication that it's caused by that code until you look into the deprecation warnings. 

Stability of namespaces and vocabulary is a big part of the semantic web, so it feels a like more of a fundamental breaking change when we change it up in a minor release.

Ok - I had originally though that this wouldn't be such a big issue because the use cases of directly interacting with the RDF data for config are vanishingly rare. But I agree that I may have underestimated that and we really should be treating this as a breaking change.

I suggest that, instead of trying to "fix" the change, we just take it out of the 4.3 release, and instead apply it on the 5.0 branch.

Update: that may not be as simple as I expected. I hadn't realized this was already merged more than 2 months ago. Github won't even let me create a revert PR from the original PR, too much has changed since then.

Ok let's suck it up, and just accept that for 4.3 we'll have ugly config files with duplicate data. I hate it, it's bad design and a bad experience for most of our users, but a breaking change is a breaking change.
I'll take a jab at cleaning it up.

@hmottestad I've just realised that we've already got a milestone out with these changes in, and I think @aschwarte10 has already prepped their product to work with this.

I don't think we can back out anymore. We either go with what we have and provide upgrade guidance, or we go with some halfway approach to make it backward compatible .

Milestone builds are not releases, so we can roll back the changes if we want to. It's not the best thing to do though, in general. 

Could you comment @aschwarte10 and let us know if you've already migrated over to the new config vocabulary that was included in the milestone build?

> Could you comment @aschwarte10 and let us know if you've already migrated over to the new config vocabulary that was included in the milestone build?

The change with the repository configuration schema has not been part of 4.3.0 M1 and thus we have not yet done any migration. We required 4.3.0 M1 mostly for the Jakarta changes in the core modules (related to Jaxb).

And even if we already did migrations:  as @hmottestad said - this is milestone releases. For me it is perfectly fine to roll back things if they do not work out. It is just important that the GA releases are in good shape.

Cool, I can live with that: fully agree that we can do this for milestones, just wanted to make sure we weren't creating a heap of extra work for metaphacts. @hmottestad really appreciate you giving a revert a go. Hopefully you can do it in a way that we can merge it into the 5.0 branch instead. Shout if you need a hand.

@abrokenjester I've introduced a system property that switches the code over to only using the new CONFIG vocabulary. I've only reverted some of the test code, other than that I've kept all the CONFIG code to make it easier to switch over in 5.0.0.
commit_messages: GH-4532 fix breaking changes (#4533)

comments: Since the old config classes are probably widely in use by users I think it might be a good idea to not remove them in 5.0.0 and leave them around until 6.0.0 so that users have extra long time to migrate their code.
Not sure why the PR verify is failing because the xml-format plugin can't be found.

> @abrokenjester I was looking at the new CONFIG class that you introduced and have some suggestions for changes.
> 
> I propose we use Config instead of CONFIG. I haven't looked into why you went with CONFIG to begin with, but I was thinking that it breaks with our current naming conventions and I wasn't sure why.

We discussed this when I put up the original change - see https://www.eclipse.org/lists/rdf4j-dev/msg02136.html. The consensus was that we'd stick with all capitals because although that breaks with our general class naming conventions, it aligns it with the convention that we use for all other vocabulary classes. They're all named for their prefix name, in all caps.

> I also noticed that there are some new abbreviations that I think will be confusing to users. I propose using the class names for the classes that the configs apply to. So `Config.CustomGraphQueryInferencer` instead of `Config.Cgqi`. I see that it messes a bit with the IntelliJ autocomplete, so maybe we could go with a suffix of sorts?

Two things:

1. the abbreviations align with what is used in the actual URIs - so ideally if you want to change these abbreviations you'll have to adapt the actual URIs as well (and make sure that all templates are adapted, too);
2. I chose the abbreviations based on brevity, both from a Java point of view _and_ for the actual RDF vocabulary itself. I agree that some, like `Cgqi` and `Ca`, are not the most intuitive, so happy to discuss alternatives, but I'd rather not go with the full class name as that makes it all _very_ verbose.

Sorry for not following along when this was being discussed. 

The main issue with the abbreviations is that they are really hard for users to discover. They have to read the Java docs to understand that the config for the ElasticsearchStore is now in ess.

I really believe we need to help users with discoverability. Maybe we could add a constant to all the main classes that point to the relevant vocabulary. For instance ElasticsearchStore.CONFIG would be equal to CONFIG.ess, and that way we would still maintain the vocabulary in a single location without any duplication.

> The main issue with the abbreviations is that they are really hard for users to discover. They have to read the Java docs to understand that the config for the ElasticsearchStore is now in ess.

YMMV, but I don't find that "hard to discover". The IDE warns if a class or field is deprecated when you use it, as soon as you hover over it the javadoc tells you where to look for the replacement. 

That said, anything we can do to make it even easier is welcome of course :) 

> I really believe we need to help users with discoverability. Maybe we could add a constant to all the main classes that point to the relevant vocabulary. For instance ElasticsearchStore.CONFIG would be equal to CONFIG.ess, and that way we would still maintain the vocabulary in a single location without any duplication.

I like this idea.

I think I'll just leave things as they are here and instead look into adding some way to link to the relevant vocabulary from within the different sails and repos. Hopefully it's as easy as introducing a constant.

I'll think about the abbreviations for a bit and see if I can come up with anything that is cleared without being too long.

comments: @pulquero can you take a look and let me know if this looks like ok?

That might work but I think strictly the close() should be inside the try. The stream is for writing the response body. If there is an error you want to not write/close whatever body you have, abandon it and just write error headers instead.
Wouldn't it be easier to keep the try-with-resource and instead add a try/catch inside that to handle the error?

> Wouldn't it be easier to keep the try-with-resource and instead add a try/catch inside that to handle the error?

Hadn't thought of that - might be cleaner. I'll take a look and push an update.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3267  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

- updated old swagger yaml to openapi 3.0 spec draft
- added static webpage that renders the spec as redoc on the website
- removed old hand-written rest api documentation: openapi spec is a replacement

This openapi spec can possible be improved further, both from a code-generation/testing pov as from a documentation pov, but I'd like us to switch over this ASAP as it will be easier to maintain and improve than the old hand-written docs.


----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [x] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [x] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [x] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments:
> Not an OpenAPI expert, but it seems that the rdf4j-openapi.yaml has a few errors (i.e. copy/pasting it into https://editor.swagger.io/ produces errors on the XML-examples and some issues on properties). So perhaps something to look into...

Argh, I thought I had fixed all those. Good catch, I'll tidy that up.

> I need to run this up locally to see what it looks like. I'm glad you've taken the time to modernise our API documentation :)

Tip for others who may not know this: if you have `hugo` installed on your local machine, you can just run `hugo server --disableFastRender` in the `site/` directory, and you can then view the site at http://localhost:1313/.

I'm going to merge this this weekend unless there are major objections. I want to merge while I have time to monitor (and if necessary fix) the website (unsure if our use of the redoc script may trigger one of our site security rules, if so I'll need to tweak that to keep the site from breaking).

GitHub issue resolved: #4482

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

I replace the IRI by CoreDatatype, I hope it is fine without any test knowing how trivial it is.

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

comments:
> The fix looks good to me. Given that this is a bug fix could you rebase your fix on the main branch so we can merge it into main instead of develop?

done :)

This could potentially be a performance issue for literals that lazy load the CoreDatatype. I don't think it's a big problem though since the code essentially replaces a string equals. 

Btw. You can use == instead of .equals(...) since it's not allowed to return null as a CoreDatatype.

> This could potentially be a performance issue for literals that lazy load the CoreDatatype. I don't think it's a big problem though since the code essentially replaces a string equals.
> 
> Btw. You can use == instead of .equals(...) since it's not allowed to return null as a CoreDatatype.

I've replaced the equals to ==, but you're not understanding the issue I think, the issue wasn't the performances, the issue was as explained in #4482 that the previous code was comparing the datatype IRI to the core datatype. So it was false all the time and was displaying `"aaa"^^xsd:string` with a call to toString

I understood the issue. It's a good fix. I was just mentioning a possible performance implication, but the alternative is to compare the datatype IRI instead, and that typically results in a string comparison. So I think sticking to CoreDatatype is the best, just like what you have done :)

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4474

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

By publishing "classes" artifacts from war modules we avoid the duplicated dependency management in modules using the war to run tests with a test server. In this PR I fix the two compliance modules running tests using a test server. The federation module desperately need some care, but I'll leave this for a follow-up PR. I suspect we need to establish a dedicated module for the federation tests to fix this - as the compliance modules are for their corresponding functional module.

comments:
I tried to make it even a bit more robust. https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4467

What do you think?

> I tried to make it even a bit more robust. #4467
> 
> What do you think?

No offense, but have we ever considered http://www.awaitility.org/ in this project? IMO it makes async test code a lot more readable compared to writing our own sleep/loops/timeouts. It also works well with AssertJ: https://github.com/awaitility/awaitility/wiki/Usage#using-assertj-or-fest-assert

I'll suggest merging this thread-safety fix into main now, merge up to develop and then try out Awaitility in a PR targeting develop.

Haven‚Äôt heard of awaitability before. Looks decent enough and it‚Äôs licensed with Apache 2.0, so it shouldn‚Äôt be too hard getting it through the IP check. 

I merged my branch so I‚Äôll close this one.

This PR replaces the maven plugin that can be used to run server/workbench in a local development environment. I am now able to run server in standalone mode by executing `mvn jetty:run` from the server module, and workbench+server if running from the workbench module.

body: This PR is a draft for an overhaul of the Java EE dependencies in the project. To support/verify this, I also added a few maven-enforcer-plugin executions - to highlight which modules that may require special attention when trying to upgrade Java/Jakarta EE.
comments: @abrokenjester Does this draft PR make sense to you? I am open to dropping the maven-enforcer-plugin configuration, as it became a bit complex. But it verifies/checks the main goal in this PR: overhaul/reduce the Java/Jakarta EE dependencies.

@erikgb sorry for not responding sooner - this PR somehow wasn't on my "to review" radar. 

It's problematic for me to really review this as well, as my knowledge of (current) Java EE and Jakarta is really limited. In short, I'm simply not really sure what this is trying to achieve. Could you perhaps add some review comments inline yourself to explain what this is doing and why? 

EDIT - I took another look and I think that jogged my brain into gear a little. As I understand it, this PR tries to achieve two things:

1. remove all existing dependencies on java EE modules (the reason we want this is to enable us to switch to Jakarta later on?)
2. add something in the enforcer plugin to make sure we don't accidentally put them back in?

More generally though I am still a little lost in the various Java EE / Jakarta-related PRs that have been put up, which ones depend on which, and which ones are on the critical path. It would really help if you linked each PR with a concrete issue that describes what needs solving.

@abrokenjester Sorry for being slow on the iterations, but I have been busy with other things lately. I'll probably pull out some cleanup of unused J2EE dependencies from this PR to a new issue + PR and close this PR. The suggested enforcer configuration will probably create more confusion than good. I think reducing J2EE/Jakarta dependencies will improve the codebase, at least the stated, but unneeded dependencies.
Seems like the unused J2EE dependencies are already removed. Closing.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4431 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

This PR migrates all use of WireMock in the codebase to MockServer. MockServer is built on Netty, and provides no-dependency shaded jars, which will ease upgrading Jetty (https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4252), upgrade Java/Jakarta EE and migrate from Java EE to Jakarta EE (https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/3559).

The MockServer code is a bit more verbose, but fairly equivalent to WireMock. MockServer lacks the ability to load mocked response bodies from file, so in order to not change "everything" in this PR, I added small utility methods to adapt this missing feature. This can be changed/improved in a follow-up PR.

----

body:
I have been looking at migrating the JUnit4 test suites to JUnit5, and it is definitely not straightforward. If https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/456 was resolved, that could help, but I am not sure if the JUnit5 test suite concept really is what we want.

This PR suggests migrating these test suites to JUnit5 by replacing the suite declaration with JUnit5 [nested tests](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-nested). @abrokenjester @hmottestad WDYT? This can be improved further, but I tried to make minimal changes in the initial migration. I can create a new issue and PR if you think this looks promising. Please let me know.
This is a POC demostrating how https://mjeanroy.dev/junit-servers/jetty/jupiter could fix https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/3507.
comments: Closing i favor of https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4464

@abrokenjester I would like to have this in the milestone build since it's useful for a project I'm working on at the office.

Changed it to all caps. This entire module is marked as experimental, so we can easily change it later if we want. 

We use all caps for the core data types too. That's a bit late to change now I think, but it would have been a lot more concise if we had used the exact same case as the local names. E.g. CoreDatatype.XSD.gMonthDay instead of CoreDatatype.XSD.GMONTHDAY. Also sometimes we use underscore and sometimes we don't, e.g. NON_POSITIVE_INTEGER but not with NORMALIZEDSTRING. It's inherited from the original XSD vocabulary naming, so at least it's consistent.

GitHub issue resolved: #4430  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
Provide more user-friendly error message when trying to parse invalid content with BinaryQueryResultParser.
When BinaryQueryResultParser gets unknown symbol, the remaining bytes from the result are parsed as string in order to provide more user-friendly error message. Also, introduced limit of the returned string, if its length > INVALID_CONTENT_LIMIT, it is trimmed and "..." is appended in order to prevent displaying too long result.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4421

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

This PR eliminates dependencies to` javax.xml.bind` from core libraries. Main motivation being to ease the javax->jakarta migration, ref. #3559.

- Base64 encoding now uses the standard Java library support added in Java 8
- To perform Hex encoding, I am proposing to use commons-codec for now,. But it should be fairly simple to write our own utility method if that is an unwanted dependency. And migrate to the standard Java library support added in Java 17 - once Java 17 becomes the minimum supported version.

----

Kudos to @aschwarte10 for the test additions.
comments:
> You are currently targeting the `main` branch (i.e. a patch release like 4.2.x). I am not sure whether we can add a new dependency to one of the modules in a patch release. We for instance do resolution of transitive dependencies manually by listing them explicitly (i.e. we do not rely on the modules POM). Maybe it would be better to target the develop branch and go for a 4.3.0 release?

I see. I am happy to do whatever the maintainers think is best. To avoid the new dependency, it should be pretty straight-forward to write a custom method to do hex-encoding.

> In addition: did you check that unit test cases exist? At least for `AbstractRDFParser#createNode(String nodeID)` it should be straight forward to create them (to check before / after)

No, I did not, but good point. I assumed this piece of code had test coverage. Ideally, tests should be added before this PR. Anything you could contribute? I am not sure how the tests would look like....

The changes look good to me! Thanks for handling this @erikgb . 

As for test coverage, I'm not sure how this exactly impacts things...so it would be great if @jetztgradnet could contribute some tests.

I also agree that this should be merged into the develop branch to be targeted at next minor build.

> I also agree that this should be merged into the develop branch to be targeted at next minor build.

PR updated to target the develop branch.

> Can you also please have a look at why the java 19 test is failing?

I am pretty sure it is a flake. We'll see on the next push, as I don't see a way to retrigger CI jobs. Runs fine locally, and seems totally unrelated to the change.
Thanks again for the test input, @aschwarte10! ‚ù§Ô∏è I have added the test cases now, using JUnit 5 parametrized tests (more compact).
For the flaky test, I created https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4434 after observing the same test failing in another PR.
Thanks, @erikgb, for your implementation! I will test this in my current migration project.

I tested this branch in my migration project and this solved my issued with the dependencies to `javax.xml.bind`
Would be great to have this merged soon and ideally with a 4.3.0-M1 milestone build published soon after :-)

Good point by @hmottestad. I hadn't thought of it, but the modules in `testsuite/` are, strictly speaking, production code as they are released as reusable modules for 3rd party implementations of e.g. SAILs to use for compliance checking.

As for the branching model, it's explained here: https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/workflow/ . Though we are currently in a bit of an odd situation in that we have _third_ long-term branch for tracking 5.0 development.

Following up on this: what I said above is true but I just realised we already merged another PR with JUnit 5 upgrades to main, and that PR also contained changes to the testsuites. @hmottestad given that that's the case I suggest that instead of rebasing these open PRs against develop we just go with it and push it through on main. body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4401  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Update of configuration vocabularies to use a single namespace following the tag URI scheme. Aims are to 

- simplify configuration and make config files easier to read
- remove references to obsolete openrdf.org domain
- introduce new vocabulary in backward-compatible manner: the code should be able to read both the new config format and the old (or even a mix). 

We will likely want a followup at some point to create automatic migration of existing configs, before we can fully remove the old vocabulary.

> This should probably be targeted at develop.

Probably yes, but I suspect we cannot upgrade to Jakarta EE 8 because of no WireMock version supporting that. Seems like they went straight for Jakarta EE 9.

Fwiw we use WireMock in a very limited part of the project only and despite me introducing it, I've never really been a massive fan of it. If we can rework those tests to use something else I don't mind just ripping WireMock out (not sure if I'm opening a can of worms here though)

If wiremock is used in the spring-part,  e.g https://rest-assured.io with springmockvc could be an alternative

> Fwiw we use WireMock in a very limited part of the project only and despite me introducing it, I've never really been a massive fan of it. If we can rework those tests to use something else I don't mind just ripping WireMock out (not sure if I'm opening a can of worms here though)

I'll support ripping WireMock out, mainly because it is tightly coupled with Java/Jakarta EE and Jetty. Maybe a spring-managed dependency could be used as a replacement - even in core modules - as this affects the test classpath only? Maybe create an issue for it?

Maybe https://www.mock-server.com/ could be another alternative to (closer to) WireMock. I don't have any experience with https://rest-assured.io/, but it seems to solve a bit different use case than WireMock/MockServer.

I created a POC draft PR for migrating to MockServer: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4429/files

It seems like we will get more verbose code, but the migration is fairly simple. I could finalize this if we decide to head in that direction. @abrokenjester @barthanssens @hmottestad

WireMock seems to be a blocker for a couple of tasks at present.....
Further progress is currently blocked by https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4439. Would be good to have that PR reviewed and merged.

> Further progress is currently blocked by #4439. Would be good to have that PR reviewed and merged.

Probably also semi-blocked by https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4437. At least it would be a lot simpler to upgrade Jetty (or migrate to Tomcat) if using JUnit Server. Actually, I think migrating to Tomcat for our test-servers would make a lot of sense because Elastic/Solr seem to depend on Jetty - which makes it harder to upgrade. Ref. the failing integration-tests: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/actions/runs/4217370690/jobs/7321097966

Wow, CI is finally green! A minor hack for the conflicting Jetty dependency pulled in from the Solr dependencies. I really really would like some input on how to get this change in somehow. So before I create a new PR and probably an issue, it would be very nice to know what you think:
- Which branch should I target? This is probably a breaking change for some users - as JavaEE/JakartaEE is upgraded by one major version.
- Is the suggested hack to overcome the Solr -> Jetty dependencies ok? It is really painful to share direct dependencies with some of our dependencies. Can this be avoided somehow? Maybe @barthanssens can take a look at the major upgrade of Solr required to make the JavaEE/JakartaEE upgrade smoother.

I've found the following issues relevant to this PR: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/3559 https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4252 https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4441

@abrokenjester @hmottestad

@erikgb as the branch develop is now targeting RDF4j 5.x I think that is the right branch to target.
I would also not mind if you go straight to jakarta ee 9 with this change now.

> I would also not mind if you go straight to jakarta ee 9 with this change now.

I am not sure if that will work. Jakarta EE 9 migrates all classes from `javax.*` to `jakarta.*`, so that would be A LOT more changes. Also there is no version of Solr that support Jakarta EE 9.

GitHub issue resolved: #4384

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

This PR migrates a lot of our code to JUnit 5 and removes the all-include dependency to junit-vintage-engine. This will make it easier to work in modules without dependency to JUnit 4 by reducing the number of multiple import alternatives.

I've migrated as much as I found reasonable without digging into full rewrites that would make the PR un-reviewable. I will create an issue with a summary of the remaining migration, even if I tried to add comments to the unwanted vintage dependency declarations in POMs.

@jeenbroekstra I think I have now reached a point where I don't think I should migrate more to JUnit 5. There are already a lot of changed lines, but I still think it should be reviewable. üòâ Since this is no longer a _full_ migration to JUnit 5, I should probably create a new PR. Should I also create a corresponding issue, or could I relate it to the existing issue, but without closing it?

I will of course rebase and squash everything and ensure all tests pass.

> @jeenbroekstra I think I have now reached a point where I don't think I should migrate more to JUnit 5. There are already a lot of changed lines, but I still think it should be reviewable. üòâ Since this is no longer a _full_ migration to JUnit 5, I should probably create a new PR. Should I also create a corresponding issue, or could I relate it to the existing issue, but without closing it?

I'm happy to just keep this PR and have it close the existing ticket, tbh (perhaps we can take the "Full" out of the issue title). 

If you can, perhaps just stick a new followup ticket in the backlog enumerating (some of) the tests that _haven't_ been migrated yet. 

> I will of course rebase and squash everything and ensure all tests pass.

Great work, thanks!

@jeenbroekstra Are you able to review this PR? A lot of changed files, but I have tried to make things reviewable. It would be nice to get this merged soon, as any other PR merged ahead of this could potentially create a bit of chaos. And I assume we would like to migrate as much as possible to JUnit 5, and I think this is a pretty good start. üòâ

@abrokenjester I see that this PR affects classes in the "RDF4J: Test Suites" module. I think that module is published to maven central. It could be that others are using our test suite to check if their own code is compliance. In that case we could end up breaking their code if they don't also upgrade to JUnit 5. I haven't read through the changes in this PR to see if that is the case, so it might be a non-issue.
