It took me a while longer than expected to get back to this (the docker ecosystem is even more of a hot mess than I remember from when I last had to reinstall this stuff - took me six attempts to install the correct versions of all the bits). 

Unfortunately, when trying to upload an RDF file via the workbench, immediately ran into this:

```
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to process parts as no multi-part configuration has been provided
	org.apache.catalina.connector.Request.parseParts(Request.java:2905)
	org.apache.catalina.connector.Request.getParts(Request.java:2873)
	org.apache.catalina.connector.RequestFacade.getParts(RequestFacade.java:1086)
	javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequestWrapper.getParts(HttpServletRequestWrapper.java:349)
	javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequestWrapper.getParts(HttpServletRequestWrapper.java:349)
	javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequestWrapper.getParts(HttpServletRequestWrapper.java:349)
	javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequestWrapper.getParts(HttpServletRequestWrapper.java:349)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.util.WorkbenchRequest.getMultipartParameterMap(WorkbenchRequest.java:284)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.util.WorkbenchRequest.<init>(WorkbenchRequest.java:74)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.base.TransformationServlet.service(TransformationServlet.java:96)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.base.AbstractServlet.service(AbstractServlet.java:129)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.ProxyRepositoryServlet.service(ProxyRepositoryServlet.java:100)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.WorkbenchServlet.service(WorkbenchServlet.java:215)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.WorkbenchServlet.handleRequest(WorkbenchServlet.java:137)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.WorkbenchServlet.service(WorkbenchServlet.java:112)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.WorkbenchGateway.service(WorkbenchGateway.java:117)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.base.AbstractServlet.service(AbstractServlet.java:129)
	org.apache.tomcat.websocket.server.WsFilter.doFilter(WsFilter.java:52)
	org.apache.catalina.filters.SetCharacterEncodingFilter.doFilter(SetCharacterEncodingFilter.java:109)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.CacheFilter.doFilter(CacheFilter.java:64)
	org.eclipse.rdf4j.workbench.proxy.CookieCacheControlFilter.doFilter(CookieCacheControlFilter.java:56)
```

I'll take a look if adding the annotation in `AddServlet` is enough to fix things.

It does not seem to a case of simply adding this to `AddServlet` :(  I'm afraid you're going to have to tweak/test things a bit more on your end @erikgb . 

You can find some instructions on how to build and run a local docker image in `docker/README_DEV.md`. Or if you prefer not to use docker, you can also run `mvn -Pquick clean install` from the workbench dir and then manually deploy the created warfile in a local Tomcat installation.
@abrokenjester No worries! I suspected this, and will take another look. Could you share your test setup, or is it documented somewhere?
Sorry, I need to read before I write. üòÇ

@erikgb yeah good point, I had logged a ticket for the docker issues (https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4399) but I haven't pushed changes through yet. I'll make that a priority because it saves a lot of hassle.

After seeing this comment in `WorkbenchGateway`:

> All requests are serviced by this Servlet, though it usually delegates to other Servlets.

And being able to run the workbench locally after https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4447, I think this works now! üòÖ It was simpler to change than expected.

Maybe you can take another look @abrokenjester?

> Tested locally and workbench appears to work fine. Tested file uploads, exports, queries, updates, and repo creation. üëç

Thanks for verifying, @abrokenjester! ‚ù§Ô∏è Could we get this merged?

comments:
@jeenbroekstra How do you suggest I split this PR in multiple issues/PRs? I don't think we should merge this as a "big thing". üòâ Fixing deprecation warnings will surely ease https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/3559, as this will require bumping versions to a version where deprecated features are removed.

Is Dependabot enabled on this project at present? Some dependencies seems to lag behind, but there might be other reasons for that.

> @jeenbroekstra How do you suggest I split this PR in multiple issues/PRs? I don't think we should merge this as a "big thing". üòâ Fixing deprecation warnings will surely ease #3559, as this will require bumping versions to a version where deprecated features are removed.

Perhaps split out by library for which you're fixing deprecations? That way you can also track the reason _why_ you're fixing these more easily: presumably it is because you want to upgrade to a version of that library that no longer supports the deprecated pattern. So I'd suggest to stick in an issue card for each library you want to bump and link a PR that updates its usage.

> Is Dependabot enabled on this project at present? Some dependencies seems to lag behind, but there might be other reasons for that.

It is. But dependabot only flags security concerns - it doesn't automatically bump everything for which a new version exists.
Thanks, makes a lot of sense. I already started with Spring, and will probably continue with Jackson.

Closing this, as there are currently too many internal deprecation warnings to work effectively with this task. We can return to this when the use of internal deprecated APIs is removed preparing for the next major version.

body:
and replace it with multipart support added in Servlet 3.0.

GitHub issue resolved: # <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

commons-fileupload hasn't had any release since 2018, and is not really required - as Java EE added support for multipart handling in Servlet 3.0, ref. https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/servlets011.htm

Removing the dependency to commons-fileupload is a pre-requirement to the javax -> jakarta migration proposed in https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/3559.

I did the simplest thing to remove the dependency, and IMO the affected code should be refactored more, but I am leaving this to a follow-up PR.

Thanks. Apart from verifying the new multipart setup, I have tried to do a safe refactoring, so I do not expect any issues when multipart request works at all.

Sorry, I probably don't have the bandwidth to add additional tests now. According to @hmottestad there are some tests that could be enabled in CI, ref. https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/discussions/4370#discussioncomment-4717478
Superseeded by https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4375, closing.

For some reason the dashlicense tool fails to clear the elasticsearch-high-level-client, looks like the tool receives a JSON response with a misspelled label ("apporoved" instead of "approved")

> For some reason the dashlicense tool fails to clear the elasticsearch-high-level-client, looks like the tool receives a JSON response with a misspelled label ("apporoved" instead of "approved")

Can we report that somewhere? 

I haven't looked at the github action in too much detail but if this is the only thing holding us up, can we add it in as a "skip" / "ignore" in its config for now? We can merge regardless of course, but I'd rather not have this error start flaring up for every pull request after - would make the license check useless.

> > For some reason the dashlicense tool fails to clear the elasticsearch-high-level-client, looks like the tool receives a JSON response with a misspelled label ("apporoved" instead of "approved")
> 
> Can we report that somewhere?
> 
I mentioned it to Rahul (via private chat on the new matrix.eclipse chat room), so hopefully it gets fixed soon
Hmz ok, now the elastic-search-client is ok, but ES itself is 'restricted', I'll check with Eclipse
Ok, chatted with Rahul, apparently we can safely ignore the restricted label on ES by the dash tool: it's been marked "approved" in IPlab for our RDF4J use case
For good measure, I'll add a few lines on the ES-licensing on the website https://rdf4j.org/documentation/reference/configuration/#elasticsearch-store

As far as I'm concerned, the PR is complete: added a note on the ES license, licenses of the dependencies in IPlab cleared

(only an issue with dash tool for ES itself, but that seems to be an internal Eclipse issue because of some manual steps in syncing IPlab and the dash-license backend)

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4232 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

-  ensure VALUES clause always covers entire group graph pattern. This is the generically correct way to parse VALUES clauses. An optimizer can potentially look at the ordering in the algebra to push the values clause down into the join tree (by inspecting which parts of the tree have variables bound in the VALUES clause).
- adding benchmarks 


----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [ ] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [ ] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments:
Results from my laptop:

```
Benchmark                                          Mode  Cnt    Score   Error  Units
SPARQLValuesClauseBenchmark.simpleEquivalentQuery  avgt    5    0.606 ¬± 0.007  ms/op
SPARQLValuesClauseBenchmark.valuesOptionalQuery    avgt    5  298.065 ¬± 6.825  ms/op
```

The query with the VALUES clause uses ~300ms per query while the other query uses ~0.6ms.

On my laptop:

```
Benchmark                                          Mode  Cnt    Score    Error  Units
SPARQLValuesClauseBenchmark.simpleEquivalentQuery  avgt    5    0.956 ¬±  0.093  ms/op
SPARQLValuesClauseBenchmark.valuesOptionalQuery    avgt    5  452.636 ¬± 23.386  ms/op
```

Looks like you have a slightly better laptop :)

Query explanation simple query:

```
Projection (resultSizeActual=505)
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêProjectionElemList
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "parent"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "child"
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêLeftJoin (LeftJoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=505)
   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄStatementPattern (resultSizeEstimate=504, resultSizeActual=504)
   ‚îÇ     Var (name=parent)
   ‚îÇ     Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ     Var (name=_const_7e619dcc_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class, anonymous)
   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄJoin (JoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=2)
      ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=50, resultSizeEstimate=9.9K, resultSizeActual=2)
      ‚ïë     Var (name=child)
      ‚ïë     Var (name=_const_4592be07_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#subClassOf, anonymous)
      ‚ïë     Var (name=parent)
      ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=504, resultSizeActual=2)
            Var (name=child)
            Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
            Var (name=_const_7e619dcc_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class, anonymous)
```

Query explanation values clause query:

```
Projection (resultSizeActual=505)
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêProjectionElemList
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "parent"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "child"
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêLeftJoin (LeftJoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=505)
   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄJoin (JoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=504)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêBindingSetAssignment ([[type=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class]]) (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=1, resultSizeActual=1)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=504, resultSizeEstimate=504, resultSizeActual=504)
   ‚îÇ        Var (name=parent)
   ‚îÇ        Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ        Var (name=type, value=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class)
   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄJoin (JoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=2)
      ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=11, resultSizeEstimate=508, resultSizeActual=254.0K)
      ‚ïë     Var (name=child)
      ‚ïë     Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
      ‚ïë     Var (name=type)
      ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=9.9K, resultSizeActual=2)
            Var (name=child)
            Var (name=_const_4592be07_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#subClassOf, anonymous)
            Var (name=parent)
```

I still can't see exactly what goes wrong, other than that it just seems to be a pathological case in terms of the data shape. I'm starting to wonder if we should have an optimizer that just duplicates the bindingsetassignment clause into the right arg of the left join. We can't pre-bind values in the right arg of the left join, but perhaps if we optimize to something like this:

```
Projection (resultSizeActual=505)
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêProjectionElemList
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "parent"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "child"
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêLeftJoin (LeftJoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=505)
   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄJoin (JoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=504)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêBindingSetAssignment ([[type=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class]]) (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=1, resultSizeActual=1)
   ‚îÇ  ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=504, resultSizeEstimate=504, resultSizeActual=504)
   ‚îÇ        Var (name=parent)
   ‚îÇ        Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ        Var (name=type, value=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class)
   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄJoin (JoinIterator) (resultSizeActual=2)
      ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïê Join
           -> BindingSetAssignment ([[type=http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class]]) (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=1, resultSizeActual=1)
           ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=11, resultSizeEstimate=508, resultSizeActual=254.0K)
           ‚ïë     Var (name=child)
           ‚ïë     Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
           ‚ïë     Var (name=type)
           ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=9.9K, resultSizeActual=2)
                   Var (name=child)
                  Var (name=_const_4592be07_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#subClassOf, anonymous)
                 Var (name=parent)
```

(ugly manual editing by me to get the idea across)

I'm not yet sure if that is something that is generally legal tbh. Just recording my thoughts for the next time I revisit.

In this case I think it's an issue with the join optimizer. The join optimizer doesn't really need to be limited by scoping issues when it calculates cardinality, as long as any optimizations are legal. 

The join optimizer could assume that the binding set assignment will apply and use it to both calculate the size and to ignore the positive effect that binding the `?type` variable early will have.

> In this case I think it's an issue with the join optimizer. The join optimizer doesn't really need to be limited by scoping issues when it calculates cardinality, as long as any optimizations are legal.
> 
> The join optimizer could assume that the binding set assignment will apply and use it to both calculate the size and to ignore the positive effect that binding the `?type` variable early will have.

I don't quite understand what you're getting at. As far as I can tell the problem is that the join optimizer calculates an initial cost for the `(?child, type, ?type)` pattern that is lower than it should be due to its base cardinality being lower than that of the `(?child, subClassOf, ?parent)` pattern. I'm struggling to see how to accurately compensate here though, to be honest. How can we inform it at the time of cost calculation that `?type` is different from `?parent` because the former is set by a BSA?

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #2061
Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
This introduces a new collection factory backed by mapdb3.
However, at this point it is a new option and not yet configured or used by any specific sail.


----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

comments: @barthanssens as you looked at upgrading to MapDB v3 last, this is part of how the upgrade would look using the collection-factory-api approach.
Thanks Jerven. Last time I've checked, the performance of MapDB 3.0 was less than v1.0 for our purposes... is this still the case ?

With a bit more code this can be made about twice as fast. Mostly by being smarter in the serialization logic.
At this point I wanted to show a minimal patch before adding all that complication.
@barthanssens  would you mind having a look now? MapDb3 is not enabled by default now. But I think with the serializer changes this will be faster than before.

So the main difference in performance in mapdb1/3 is the change of per default not using a mmap'ed backing file.

Re-enabling those is the difference is in favor of the MapDB3 version as implemented.

I added a mini bechmark and here are the results, from my desktop.

Mapdb v1
```
Benchmark                               (bsSize)  (size)  Mode  Cnt     Score      Error  Units
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets         1    1000  avgt    5    87.525 ¬±    3.561  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets         1   10000  avgt    5   939.715 ¬± 1189.716  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets       129    1000  avgt    5   253.713 ¬±  141.265  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets       129   10000  avgt    5  2746.326 ¬± 2007.078  ms/op
```

Mapdb v3 default / random access file
```
Benchmark                               (bsSize)  (size)  Mode  Cnt     Score      Error  Units
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets         1    1000  avgt    5   273.790 ¬±   10.971  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets         1   10000  avgt    5  1638.240 ¬±  162.203  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets       129    1000  avgt    5   296.656 ¬±   61.370  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets       129   10000  avgt    5  2158.207 ¬± 1006.500  ms/op
```
note the significant regression for small maps.

Mapdb v3 mmap
```
Benchmark                               (bsSize)  (size)  Mode  Cnt    Score     Error  Units
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets         1    1000  avgt    5   44.043 ¬±  30.838  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets         1   10000  avgt    5  165.744 ¬± 306.912  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets       129    1000  avgt    5   56.928 ¬±   3.357  ms/op
BindingSetMapBenchmark.saveBindingSets       129   10000  avgt    5  777.638 ¬± 491.015  ms/op
```
note the significant speed up.

This was not on a truly idle machine which leads to the large uncertainty. So I will rerun this in clean fashion at some point, but I believe the numbers are representative.
@hmottestad FYI I hope to merge this once 4.3.0 is out of the door. While not enabled by default, I think it is best to not include last minute additions in the 4.3.0 release.

GitHub issue resolved: #3843

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

This introduces a minimal set of patches with the concept of collection factories that may be used during query evaluation.
At this point there are no "special" collection factories nor are they used as much as they should. 
The patch series should be reviewable.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/797185/206470637-ab537fbf-362f-441f-a2b4-2aa4c154bafd.png)
Hmz, looks like you've accidentally committed fixes for (white space) formatting issues in a series of unrelated files

> Hmz, looks like you've accidentally committed fixes for (white space) formatting issues in a series of unrelated files

I got a bit ahead of myself by upgrading a bunch of build time dependencies while I was at it, but then I realise I would be spending the entire weekend filing CQs for them...so I reverted those changes. The only "unrelated" thing I'm keeping is some performance improvements to the maven build.

> I got a bit ahead of myself by upgrading a bunch of build time dependencies while I was at it, but then I realise I would be spending the entire weekend filing CQs for them...so I reverted those changes.

Have you tested the Eclipse dash-license tool ? Filing CQs is now a (mostly) automated process... a much nicer experience than manually adding CQs and attaching jars via the old website ...

> > I got a bit ahead of myself by upgrading a bunch of build time dependencies while I was at it, but then I realise I would be spending the entire weekend filing CQs for them...so I reverted those changes.
> 
> Have you tested the Eclipse dash-license tool ? Filing CQs is now a (mostly) automated process... a much nicer experience than manually adding CQs and attaching jars via the old website ...

It didn't pick up any of the maven plugins :(

Fwiw I think we don't really have to file CQs for maven plugins anymore. We did so in the past, but it later turned out that we have a lot of discretion there. Especially as we don't actually distribute these, they're just part of our build env.

body:
Signed-off-by: Dzerom Dzenkins <dzeri96@proton.me>


GitHub issue resolved: #2749

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

As suggested by @jeenbroekstra, I've added a call to `setNamespace` for all new namespaces coming from the imported `Statement`s, and I've removed the appropriate overrides in the SPARQL repository, as it seems like the code was almost identical. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

Since this is a WIP, there are some things to clear up:
1. Where do I put the unit tests for this? I couldn't find an appropriate place with similar tests.
2. What should we do with the deprecated `Iteration` overload of the `add` method? I suspect this might get removed with the next release so I haven't added any changes there.
3. What about the `remove` method? Should we prune unused `Namespace`s?

As soon as these questions are cleared up, and the flaky tests are fixed, I'll continue working on this PR!

----

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4256 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

From the spec: 

> Variables in the pattern that are bound in the current [solution mapping](http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/#defn_sparqlSolutionMapping) take the value that they have from the solution mapping. Variables in the pattern pattern that are not bound in the current solution mapping take part in pattern matching.

https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/#func-filter-exists

I've removed the check for `isPartOfSubQuery` because it seems to be related to some legacy code that is no longer in use.

GitHub issue resolved: #4235


Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

The indexing analyzer is configurable, however, this is only half the
problem because if we query with a different analyzer than what's
indexed, we will end up missing a number of results (particularly as it
pertains to stopwords and stemming). For the cases where you want
to configure the indexing analyzer, we should also be allowed to
configure the query analyzer.

One minor thingie perhaps: since it's a feature, could you rebase it onto the develop branch, instead of main (main is mostly used for bug fixing) ?
All right, finally got it fixed up. I didn't realize there was a separate branch.

The documentation says start from main:

GitHub issue resolved: #4214

Previously DESCRIBE queries (when targeting a single source, i.e. a single federation member) could run into a QueryEvaluationException.

This change now completes the code path for evaluating single source DESCRIBE queries in the the TripleSource by treating them in the same way as CONSTRUCT queries.

Scenario covered with a simulated unit test.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4131

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Introduce support for custom Variance & Standard Deviation aggregate functions through magic predicates.

In total 4 magic predicates have been added with support for standard deviation & variance calculation based on sample & population formulas.

 The added magic predicates and subsequent functions include:
- <http://rdf4j.org/aggregate#variance_sample> - used to calculate variance based on sample assumption (e.g. N-1 variation)
- <http://rdf4j.org/aggregate#variance> - used to calculate variance based on population assumption 
-  <http://rdf4j.org/aggregate#stdev> - used to calculate standard deviation based on population assumption 
-  <http://rdf4j.org/aggregate#stdev_sample> - used to calculate standard deviation based on sample assumption
comments:
I'm also wondering if the variance and stdev implementations are storing all the values?

I think https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-math/apidocs/org/apache/commons/math4/stat/descriptive/SummaryStatistics.html can do some stats calculations without storing all the values. Does that cover our needs here? Would we need a CQ?

We are allowed to use Apache Commons Math3 3.6.1: https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22025

This also has the SummaryStatistics class: https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-math/javadocs/api-3.6.1/org/apache/commons/math3/stat/descriptive/SummaryStatistics.html

comments: @jeenbroekstra - please use this PR for the Isolation fixes.  It has your feedback updates..  I accidentally checked in some of my changes using my work email on the last PR and it failed the eca.

> @jeenbroekstra - please use this PR for the Isolation fixes. It has your feedback updates.. I accidentally checked in some of my changes using my work email on the last PR and it failed the eca.

Thanks for taking care of it! I've done that a few times myself. Btw you may know this already but you can set the e-mail address used for your commits on a specific repo by navigating to the repo root and doing `git config user.email <email>`. You can also set a global (on your current machine) default by doing `git config --global user.email <email>`.

@nguyenm100 as an aside, could you take another glance at our [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j#keen-to-contribute), in particular the points about commit messages, PR descriptions and such? For one thing, we make a point of having the Github issue number at the start of every commit message and at the start of the PR title as well. This makes it easier for us to relate changes back to the issue even after things have been merged.

No worries if occasionally something slips through of course, but I'd prefer it not to become a habit :)

body: Results of some tests were incorrect and always failing when compared to actual from SPARQLQueryComplianceTests.  This PR is to patch those results.
comments: Could you help me out a bit by explaining how I can easily run these tests locally on my laptop?

Hi, I'm using a fork of Halyard (by @pulquero) who has wired up a lot of these tests.  You can see them here: https://github.com/pulquero/Halyard/blob/latest/strategy/src/test/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/strategy/HalyardSPARQLQueryTest.java

The problem is that the testcases in the `testcases-sparql-1.1` directory are no longer in use in RDF4J itself. It was originally intended as an extension of official W3C test cases with our own additions for as we discovered them, but it quickly become too cumbersome to maintain that. 

We have switched our own testing framework for SPARQL over to the `RepositorySPARQLComplianceTestSuite`, which is not based on an manifest-based set of test data. `SPARQLQueryComplianceTest` is only still in use for running the W3C-approved manifest suites for SPARQL 1.0 and 1.1 compliance (which are in the `testcases-sparql-1.0-w3c` and `testcases-sparql-1.1-w3c` directories).

I have no objection to this PR (though I haven't checked the tests yet to see if the fixes make sense) but the real fix is that we just get rid of this old datadir and advise anyone still using it to switch to `RepositorySPARQLComplianceTestSuite` (which is much easier to work with anyway).

Is RepositorySPARQLComplianceTestSuite wired up as part of the rdf4j build and does it carry over the tests from test-cases-sparql-1.1?  I ask b/c the tests in that directory flagged some issues that were recently fixed see: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4165 & https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4164

and another issue I'll be reporting in a sec.
see: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4209

> Is RepositorySPARQLComplianceTestSuite wired up as part of the rdf4j build and does it carry over the tests from test-cases-sparql-1.1? I ask b/c the tests in that directory flagged some issues that were recently fixed see: #4165 & #4164

It is wired up as part of the build. Whether it completely covers all possible test cases in that old directory I don't know, but probably not. If you spot lack of coverage it might be good to port them over.

GitHub issue resolved: #4149 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

SHACL spec says that we should check for ill-typed literals if they are the datatype is one of the supported XSD datatypes. Easiest way to do this is to use the `XMLDatatypeUtil.isValidValue(...)` method. To allow this to be used in the SPARQL query we also introduce a custom function in the RSX namespace that calls this method.

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

comments: @jeenbroekstra do you know any built in functionality to easily check the conformance if a literal to its datatype using SPARQL? I've ended up creating a custom SPARQL function, but if there is a better way than I would prefer that!

> @jeenbroekstra do you know any built in functionality to easily check the conformance if a literal to its datatype using SPARQL? I've ended up creating a custom SPARQL function, but if there is a better way than I would prefer that!

Not behind a machine where I can easily test this, but wouldn't a cast function (which are built in) work for this? `xsd:dateTime(?lit)` will, I think, result in a type error when the input literal is not a valid datetime value.

> > @jeenbroekstra do you know any built in functionality to easily check the conformance if a literal to its datatype using SPARQL? I've ended up creating a custom SPARQL function, but if there is a better way than I would prefer that!
> 
> Not behind a machine where I can easily test this, but wouldn't a cast function (which are built in) work for this? `xsd:dateTime(?lit)` will, I think, result in a type error when the input literal is not a valid datetime value.

I gave this a shot but I couldn't get it to work for `xsd:date` because we haven't implemented a constructor function for that. The SPARQL spec is a bit obtuse about which constructor functions are required, I feel it would have been simpler if they had just included all the datatypes.

So I'm sticking with my custom function.

> > > @jeenbroekstra do you know any built in functionality to easily check the conformance if a literal to its datatype using SPARQL? I've ended up creating a custom SPARQL function, but if there is a better way than I would prefer that!
> > 
> > 
> > Not behind a machine where I can easily test this, but wouldn't a cast function (which are built in) work for this? `xsd:dateTime(?lit)` will, I think, result in a type error when the input literal is not a valid datetime value.
> 
> I gave this a shot but I couldn't get it to work for `xsd:date` because we haven't implemented a constructor function for that. The SPARQL spec is a bit obtuse about which constructor functions are required, I feel it would have been simpler if they had just included all the datatypes.

Interesting! Probably something we can look to add ourselves easily enough. 

> So I'm sticking with my custom function.

Yeah seems like a good solution.

comments: @kenwenzel here are some optimizations I'm testing out.

Looks good. I also thought about integrating the estimate functions of libmdbx into LMDB:
https://libmdbx.dqdkfa.ru/group__c__rqest.html

It should be rather easy to patch LMDB but that would also implicate that we have to maintain a patched version of the LWJGL bindings...

> Looks good. I also thought about integrating the estimate functions of libmdbx into LMDB: https://libmdbx.dqdkfa.ru/group__c__rqest.html
> 
> It should be rather easy to patch LMDB but that would also implicate that we have to maintain a patched version of the LWJGL bindings...

Do you think it would be possible to contribute it to LMDB instead?

Reading through he LMDB documentation I saw that there should be some cursor operations to get the first and last page, if the database is ordered. Maybe there is some way to estimate the size based on the addresses of the first and last page?

I remember you mentioned that you were reading a max of 1000 elements from the cursor when estimating the cardinality, is that still the case? Maybe we could do some optimized caching where we evict cardinality results based on how much resources it took to calculate them. So the cardinality for `null rdf:type null null` would be cached much longer than `:peter rdf:type null null`.

There is still the option of using the code from the ExtensibleStore which uses Hyper Log Log. I think the biggest issue with that code is that it requires refreshing if there is a lot of churn (data added and removed and then added again). During that refresh cycle it needs to read all the data from the database which would probably block all writers.

> > Looks good. I also thought about integrating the estimate functions of libmdbx into LMDB: https://libmdbx.dqdkfa.ru/group__c__rqest.html
> > It should be rather easy to patch LMDB but that would also implicate that we have to maintain a patched version of the LWJGL bindings...
> 
> Do you think it would be possible to contribute it to LMDB instead?

I've already posted a question on the OpenLDAP mailing list where I asked them to implement the feature. Unfortunately, I've got no response so far. But maybe I should offer my support regarding this topic...

> 
> Reading through he LMDB documentation I saw that there should be some cursor operations to get the first and last page, if the database is ordered. Maybe there is some way to estimate the size based on the addresses of the first and last page?

This is not possible as the keys are ordered but the b-tree pages are just randomly distributed.

> I remember you mentioned that you were reading a max of 1000 elements from the cursor when estimating the cardinality, is that still the case? Maybe we could do some optimized caching where we evict cardinality results based on how much resources it took to calculate them. So the cardinality for `null rdf:type null null` would be cached much longer than `:peter rdf:type null null`.

Yes, that is still the case. I read a fixed number of entries to determine their medium distance. Then I skip to the last key and try to extrapolate the whole number based on the distance between the keys. I'm currently working on optimizing this a bit to fix #3982.

> There is still the option of using the code from the ExtensibleStore which uses Hyper Log Log. I think the biggest issue with that code is that it requires refreshing if there is a lot of churn (data added and removed and then added again). During that refresh cycle it needs to read all the data from the database which would probably block all writers.

I also thought about implementing this but it would also require a considerable amount of storage space.

FYI - I am also working on improving the cardinality computation itself. Instead of just using the first `n` rows as samples to estimate the cardinality, I divide the whole search space into `b` buckets and then I use samples from these buckets for the estimation. I will probably push a PR this week.
@hmottestad I've tested the cardinality cache but can't see any improvments in our standard query benchmarks. Does this only pay off when using multi-threaded access?

I had a scenario with the ShaclSail where it pays off because the ShaclSail generates a lot of small and similar queries during validation. But now it's hard to reproduce because I introduced some safety checks to the query optimizer pipeline in a previous PR and those checks are very slow. Those are only enabled when assertions are enabled, so they don't affect our users.
@hmottestad Do you have any benchmarks with and without the cache?

> @hmottestad Do you have any benchmarks with and without the cache?

No. I need to create some LMDB + SHACL benchmarks.
I've looked into this branch again and I can't reproduce the initial performance issues. So I've modified the branch to only add the tests and benchmark.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4131

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Introduced custom AggregateFunctionCall abstraction that allows custom aggregate functions to be introduced through CustomAggregateFunctionRegistry. 

Updated sparql.jjt compile file and subsequently SyntaxTreeBuilder to allow distinct to be parsed for custom aggregate function calls.

Moved around abstract class for aggregate functions (Aggregate and renamed it to AggregateFunction) as well as the AggregateCollector in order to be able to define custom aggregate functions (whose signature can be the same as a standard function call) through a custom function registry (where they are validated inside the TupleExprBuilder).
comments: Will add unit & functional tests covering custom AggregateCustomFunction execution.

## Develop branch
```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt    5  5.515 ¬± 0.066  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt    5  4.784 ¬± 0.110  ms/op
```

## This branch
```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt   Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt    5  21.765 ¬± 1.686  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt    5  20.218 ¬± 0.265  ms/op
```

I presume the regression is due to the git patch files not working anymore.
I'm going to follow up on the performance regression in a separate PR.
Just realised that I merged this into main instead of develop :(

> It is still deleting all the graphs.

Could you tell me what you tested so I can try to reproduce it yourself?

Having a repository with default graph, SHACL constrains graph and two ontologie graphs and after the `con.clear(new org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.Resource[] {null});`, the default graph is cleared, SHACL constrains stay untouched, but ontologie graphs are falsely removed.
@maxstolze did you update both your client _and_ your server with this branch? Not sure if it was clear but the fix involves changes at both ends of the connection...
Will double check it now.

@jeenbroekstra @hmottestad my bad, didn't update everything properly. Sorry for the confusion. 
It is working now! So Issue fixed on our side.
This should also be back ported to  RDF4J 4.0.x.

RDF4J currently uses an old version of the apache felix plugin, this is just a dependency update for this.

By the way maybe you want enable https://github.com/dependabot for this repository to get such notifications automatically?
comments:
> RDF4J currently uses an old version of the apache felix plugin, this is just a dependency update for this.

Thanks for spotting this. We typically do (patch) dependency bumps as part of patch releases, so these kinds of PRs can be targeted at the main branch. We can merge this one as-is though, it's not a security vulnerability, so no real rush to get it done in main.

Also: can you please create a ticket for future changes? We make a habit of having an issue ticket for _every_ change, no matter how small. See [our contributor guidelines for details](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#creating-your-contribution).

> By the way maybe you want enable https://github.com/dependabot for this repository to get such notifications automatically?

Dependabot _is_ enabled. I'm not entirely sure why it didn't pick this up.

comments: I'm on mobile so can't check, but I seem to remember we added this for a specific reason:  the way we refer to the project root fails in Jenkins or in GitHub when this is not defined, I think. I'll try and look up the details in the commit history.

So we introduced this file as part of the PR that introduced automated code formatting checks (see https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/1340 ) . At the time this was done because Jenkins was having trouble with the relative path reference we use to link to the code formatting file. I can't remember if adding this was actually the fix, or if this is merely something I used to figure out the version of maven used in Jenkins.

In any case: if you want to remove it, I'd recommend running a test build on Jenkins to make sure the code formatter part of the build doesn't break there.

<dependency>

    <version>4.1.0</version>
</dependency>
```
artifact, that currently bundles everything into one big OSGi-jar. This is not optimal, but given the many RDF4J modules and its different packing (jar/war) might be a way to start instead of adding OSGi infos to each artifact individually.

 - update tests to make the unclosed iterations visible
 - add missing close() and handleClose() methods
 - close iterations in case of exceptions

comments:
Thanks for looking into the non-closed iterations. 

I did not yet have time to look into the PR in detail (will only be able to do this by Wednesday). From high level skimming the changes make sense. Regarding whether the queryInfo needs to be closed as well, I would need to double check - can't remember this from the back of my head.

May I ask in which scenario you discovered the unclosed connections? Or was it by going through the code.

Thanks for also maintaining and cleaning the code - I guess this has not been touched for a while :)

> May I ask in which scenario you discovered the unclosed connections? Or was it by going through the code.

In the past the AbstractSailConnection used to track all iterations and close them automatically when the connection was closed. I found this to be a bit of a resource hog, so instead I updated it in 4.1.0 to use a Cleaner to close them during GC. Since this doesn't guarantee that iterations are actually closed in a timely manner I've chosen to implement a counter of active iterations and then throw an exception if there are any open iterations when the connection is closed. I then ran into issues when integrating RDF4J 4.1.0-M1 with GraphDB where a test was complaining about my new exception.

> I have scanned the PR twice and did not see any obvious issues. I think this is a good way ahead and I am good to go once this is ready and all tests are passing.
> 
> Would it be possible to have another 4.1 Milestone build after this one is merged? Error handling in federation is quite difficult and even subtle changes may cause issues at runtime. With a milestone build we would be able to test this alongside our development and have even more confidence.
> 
> Thanks @hmottestad for taking the efforts üëç

I'm hoping to not have to create another milestone build. It'll still be at least another week before 4.1 is out the door, maybe you can start testing the snapshot build? If you find any critical issues we can push the release date.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #4028 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

 - add benchmark
 - when caching a plan node use ConcurrentHashMap and add debug logging
 - skip reasoning when the input class is the only inferred class and also try to return the existing statement and value as often as possible
 - reduce use of EffectiveTarget when no data has been removed
 - retrieve Resource/IRI from connection if it will be used many times
 - improve plan node caching
 - when filtering by predicate and object against the base sail we can filter against added statements first
 - fix for when addedStatements connection is null
 - reduce use of previousStateConnection and serializableConnection
 - fix for potential deadlock

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [ ] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [ ] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments: This is a bunch of improvements that I have made based on profiling the ShaclSail. Usually I would create separate issues and PRs for each change, but since all the changes here (except the deadlock fix which I have extracted [here](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4031)) are in the Shacl code I feel that it's OK doing it this way especially since creating all the issues and PRs would take longer than it took to find and fix these performance issues.

## Before
```
Benchmark                                                      Mode  Cnt      Score     Error  Units
ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallel             avgt    5   2106.630 ¬±  73.440  ms/op
ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallelNativeStore  avgt    5  10076.324 ¬± 790.517  ms/op
```

## After
```
Benchmark                                                      Mode  Cnt     Score      Error  Units
ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallel             avgt    3  2121.068 ¬±  523.925  ms/op
ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallelNativeStore  avgt    3  8151.794 ¬± 1252.501  ms/op
```

~~Need to rework this a bit. Removing the LongAdder from the HashMap when it becomes zero is problematic because it may just temporarily be zero. If I understand things correctly then once the snapshot version increments there can be no new uses of older snapshot versions. If the snapshot version is 10, and then gets incremented to 11 we can safely assume that once the counter for version 10 reaches zero that snapshot is no longer in use.~~
I think I'm just going to go ahead and merge this since it fixes some code that I merged in a previous PR, and not any existing code.

comments:
Hi,

thanks for the PR, just wondering if e.g. a `Set<Namespace>` might be more elegant.
That would also allow for (re)using the predefined namespaces from org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.vocabulary....
True! I wasn't aware of the existence of this package, I've replaced the map to a set parameter

> I'd like to make a case for using [Collections.emptyMap()](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/util/Collections.html#emptyMap()) in favor of passing around `null` for the custom prefix map. Your code would be simpler and probably safer if you could always assume the prefix map to exist. I pointed out a few bits of code that could be made more elegant with an empty map.

Yes, I was a bit lazy to check if the `PrefixDeclProcessor` was used anywhere else to be able to remove use null instead, but after a check, it is not.
Hi, is there something blocking? I'm in favour of this pull request : )

Thanks for the enhancement ! 
Perhaps the only thing left to do would be squashing the commits (see also https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing/ on how to do this, and  https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/ why this is a probably a good idea)

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

 - add support for caching cardinality for StatementPattern, TripleRef and BindingSetAssignment
 - reduce the use of HashMap for caching cardinality in QueryJoinOptimizer

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

comments: Not really showing much improvements in these benchmarks.

## Before
```
Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallel  avgt    5  2615.114 ¬± 122.301  ms/op
```

## After
```
Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt     Score    Error  Units
ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallel  avgt    5  2530.961 ¬± 30.894  ms/op
```

I've moved the cardinality caching into `AbstractQueryModelNode` together with a new method that says if the caching should be used or not, that method is then overridden in `StatementPattern`, `TripleRef` and in `BindingSetAssignment`. Further more I have reduced the need for the HashMap for tracking cardinalities, so for many queries we can skip creating the HashMap.

The benefits are fairly moderate, mostly this affects the ShaclSail which generates a lot of small queries.

comments:
## Before
```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt    5  8.314 ¬± 0.189  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt    5  7.438 ¬± 0.217  ms/op
```

## After
```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt    5  5.572 ¬± 0.070  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt    5  4.704 ¬± 0.043  ms/op
```

## Commands I used to run JavaCC

```
gh repo clone javacc/javacc 
cd javacc
ant
mkdir output
cd output     
# Now I copied the sparql.jjt file into the output directory.
chmod +x ../scripts/jjtree
chmod +x ../scripts/javacc
../scripts/jjtree sparql.jjt
../scripts/javacc sparql.jj
```

I didn't copy over any of the AST* files because most of these were not generated correctly. I don't know why. Maybe we have updated them manually?
This fixes a regression where the LookAheadException was triggering a stack trace every time the parser was instantiated. It was fixed a few years ago in JavaCC.

@jeenbroekstra I think that this branch is a good place to add some documentation and reproducibility for JavaCC. 

One major issue that I had was that the SimpleNode class was missing a bunch of methods, and that quite a few of the AST* classes were inheriting from the wrong super class and some were also missing some functionality. 

Our old SimpleNode used an ArrayList, which might be more efficient than the plain array that the generated SimpleNode uses. I don't know if this is something that we modified ourselves or if it's a change in JavaCC. I haven't put any effort into figuring it out either. 

When generating the java code there were also a couple of AST* classes that were not generated by JavaCC. That makes me wonder if maybe they were added manually instead. 

I also think that I should try to contribute some of the performance optimizations back to JavaCC, that way we don't need so many git patch files.
Sounds good. Sorry I haven't found time yet to look at this further. Will try and do so  ASAP.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #635 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

 - add new QueryEvaluationMode enum as a TransactionSetting
 - make evaluation mode configurable on a per-transaction basis
 - update repository config templates to allow setting the query evaluation mode
 - deprecate old evaluation strategy impls in favor of a single strategy that uses the mode setting to guide behaviour
 
----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [x] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [x] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [x] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments: @hmottestad I am getting test failures due to assertion errors on parent nodes in the algebra tree all over the place. It could be that my changes cause this but at first glance it seems unlikely as I'm not directly touching the algebra tree. What's the status of the develop branch with respect to this at the moment? Can you point me to recent fixes that you did in this space - it's possible that I undid some of your changes when rebasing (this branch does a lot of code refactoring).

https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4103

Also a few fixes in https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/4117

I've found the problem - it's the move of that optimizer pipeline to a new package tripping me up again. My code was still using the impl.StandardQueryOptimizerPipeline, which uses the impl optimizer classes, which have not been fixed to deal with node parent references.

We should make the deprecated optimizer classes empty subclasses of the new implementations to avoid this kind of thing - if we can.
Logged issue to fix the deprecation setup: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/4129

@hmottestad when you have a sec could you take a quick look at the failing ShaclTests I have on this PR? 

My _suspicion_ is that they fail because they were written for a store that used the StrictEvaluationStrategy, and since in this PR the stores all use StandardEvaluationStrategy (which is basically what used to be called "Extended") the results from some queries are a little different. But I'm having a hard time getting my head around the precise meaning/intent of the tests and what should be adjusted to fix.

```
select distinct ?target_0000000000 ?value {
	?target_0000000000 a <http://example.com/ns#Person> .
	?target_0000000000 <http://example.com/ns#date> ?value .
	BIND(("2018-01-01"^^<http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date> >= ?value) as ?9354941586934ef58838394e53eb08e7_0_)
	FILTER(COALESCE(?9354941586934ef58838394e53eb08e7_0_, true))
}
```

This doesn't return any result anymore.

> ```
> select distinct ?target_0000000000 ?value {
> 	?target_0000000000 a <http://example.com/ns#Person> .
> 	?target_0000000000 <http://example.com/ns#date> ?value .
> 	BIND(("2018-01-01"^^<http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date> >= ?value) as ?9354941586934ef58838394e53eb08e7_0_)
> 	FILTER(COALESCE(?9354941586934ef58838394e53eb08e7_0_, true))
> }
> ```
> 
> This doesn't return any result anymore.

I'm not sure I follow. In minExclusive case 5, when looking at the test data, `?value` will be bound to `"2018-01-02T21:00:00"^^xsd:dateTime` , which means hte comparison operator in the `BIND` will return `false`, and therefore the outcome of the `COALESCE` will be `false` and the final filter will fail - which means the query result is empty. In other words, isn't it _expected_ that this query returns no result?

> > ```
> > select distinct ?target_0000000000 ?value {
> > 	?target_0000000000 a <http://example.com/ns#Person> .
> > 	?target_0000000000 <http://example.com/ns#date> ?value .
> > 	BIND(("2018-01-01"^^<http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date> >= ?value) as ?9354941586934ef58838394e53eb08e7_0_)
> > 	FILTER(COALESCE(?9354941586934ef58838394e53eb08e7_0_, true))
> > }
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> >     
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >     
> >   
> > This doesn't return any result anymore.
> 
> I'm not sure I follow. In minExclusive case 5, when looking at the test data, `?value` will be bound to `"2018-01-02T21:00:00"^^xsd:dateTime` , which means hte comparison operator in the `BIND` will return `false`, and therefore the outcome of the `COALESCE` will be `false` and the final filter will fail - which means the query result is empty. In other words, isn't it _expected_ that this query returns no result?

To answer my own question: the difference is _probably_ that we're comparing an xsd:Date and an xsd:DateTime, which in  strict evaluation would result in a type error, but in extended/standard evaluation is allowed.
Maybe we should stick with strict mode as the default?
I presume the purpose of this PR is to allow for strict/extended to be configured per transaction. We don't really have to make any changes to the defaults now, do we?
Good point. I do want to switch to non-strict as the default if possible, but perhaps I should split that out and get the framework set up first...

Still to do:
- [x] ensure old-style strategy (factory) config is no longer part of template
- [x] ensure old-style strategy (factory) configs will still work / get converted
- [x] add prompt to set query eval mode in config
- [x] add test coverage for per-transaction/query setting of evaluation mode

Which reminds that I need to double-check that repository config in the workbench still works as exepcted.

- [x] test workbench
Assuming the build succeeds (:crossed_fingers: ) this PR is now ready for final review. I'd appreciate your thoughts, peeps.

comments: I remember I split up one of the very long methods somewhere in the generated code to help the compiler. I need to check if that is still an issue now.
@jeenbroekstra do we have some documentation for how to run JavaCC? I could never figure it out.
It's actually something I keep having to find out myself. I'll add a readme.

## Before
```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt   40  7.557 ¬± 0.022  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt   40  6.560 ¬± 0.032  ms/op
```

## After
```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt   Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt   40  23.625 ¬± 0.063  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt   40  22.240 ¬± 0.102  ms/op
```
It's about 3x slower. I think it's probably the JVM compiling issue we've run into previously.

## After splitting up the big SyntaxTreeBuilderTokenManager#jjMoveNfa_0 method

```
Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt    5  8.564 ¬± 0.857  ms/op
SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt    5  7.515 ¬± 0.403  ms/op
```

> ## After splitting up the big SyntaxTreeBuilderTokenManager#jjMoveNfa_0 method
> 
> ```
> Benchmark                                        Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
> SPARQLParseBenchmark.complexPathExpressionQuery  avgt    5  8.564 ¬± 0.857  ms/op
> SPARQLParseBenchmark.selectValuesQuery           avgt    5  7.515 ¬± 0.403  ms/op
> ```

We should do several things:

- create a patch file with this specific fix, so that we can reapply on the generated code after rerunning javacc. I suggest separate patch files for each specific fix.
- add info in a readme file on the how/why of the fix. This is necessary to help fix if the patch file no longer applies without problems (e.g when we bump javacc versions).

We have an existing patch file for this actually.

Can I propose we create some sort of script that runs JavaCC and applies all the patch files?

Then we could have a nice folder structure:
```
javaCC-sparql-generator
    patches
        large-method-jit
            README.md
            fix.patch
    script.sh
```

I've started on an issue for this here: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/issues/3962

In the mean time I would like to merge this PR. I also have a[ fix the the serializable issue](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3963) with SimpleLiteral, if you could review that for me then I will start on releasing 4.0.2 either tonight or tomorrow.

> We have an existing patch file for this actually.

Yes but none of it works, presumably because the previous version of the parser was generated with javacc 5.0. And because none of it is documented or motivated I have no idea how to update that patch (or even which parts of it are still relevant). That patch file should be deleted/replaced.

> 
> Can I propose we create some sort of script that runs JavaCC and applies all the patch files?

I don't think that's a good idea. I'd rather just document the steps. It's not fully automated, there's some inspection and adjustment involved in some steps. 

> 
> Then we could have a nice folder structure:
> ```
> javaCC-sparql-generator
>     patches
>         large-method-jit
>             README.md
>             fix.patch
>     script.sh
> ```
>
The folder structure is a good idea though and perhaps once we've got it documented, we figure out a way to script all or part of it.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3590 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Instead of tracking all iterations in a map we instead tell the JVM to automatically close them if the users has forgotten. We register the iterations with the [Java Cleaner](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/ref/Cleaner.html) (introduced in Java 9 as a better alternative to finalize) together with a Runnable that closes the iteration. The Cleaner executes the runnable when the iteration has become phantom reachable (e.g. eligible for GC). We use our existing ConcurrentCleaner which wraps an array of Cleaner instances to spread the load when objects are registered from multiple threads.

I've retained the tracking functionality for debugging purposes and it can be enabled the same way as we would previously have enabled tracking with stack traces.

A change for users will be that a connection will now `throw new SailException("Connection closed before all iterations were closed.")` if there are unclosed iterations. Before throwing this exception we call `System.gc()` multiple times to hopefully trigger the closing of any "lost" iterations. 

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3933 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
 - Made MemStatementList thread-safe and removed read/write locks.
 - MemStatementList supports the following operations:
    - read concurrently with read/add/remove
    - add concurrently with read/add
    - remove and add are mutually exclusive, and also not concurrent with other remove operations (even though this should be technically possible)
 - Added functionality to track which snapshots can be cleaned.
 - Reduced the use of volatile reads/writes in MemStatement 

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

comments: This is still very much work in progress!

Current status:
- [x] Tracking active snapshots 
- [x] Adding
- [x] Removing
- [x] Growing array
- [x] Snapshot cleanup
- [x] RAM pressure aware snapshot cleanup 
- [x] Compacting array

The existing implementation doesn't need to compact the array because it can move items around when deleting so there are never any holes in the array. ~~This doesn't work for my algorithm because there is a risk then that readers will either see an item twice or not see it at all.~~ My algorithm now solves this by allowing items to be inserted at any point in the array, so essentially it will try to fill the holes as it goes along instead of moving stuff around.
@jeenbroekstra This is still WIP but I would appreciate if you took a look to see what I'm working here.

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

 - Added [AbstractSimpleQueryModelVisitor.java](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/c8dcaef15b26b815125906debaa778aa1884fbe3/core/queryalgebra/model/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/helpers/AbstractSimpleQueryModelVisitor.java) which is a leaner and faster implementation of the QueryModelVisitor

that's a lot of wip üòÑ

Indeed. I'm extracting stuff from my big performance improvements branch and it's a lot of back and forth trying to carve out the right bits and still have all the tests pass and japicmp not complain too much. 

Performance numbers are looking good though. An overall performance boost for the MemoryStore and a 2x improvement for concurrent queries.

#### For comparison, the current state of the main branch:

```
Benchmark                                    Mode  Cnt   Score    Error  Units
ParallelQueryBenchmark.mixedQueriesAndReads  avgt    5  86.217 ¬± 10.537  ms/op

Benchmark                                                     Mode  Cnt      Score     Error  Units
QueryBenchmark.complexQuery                                   avgt    5      4.815 ¬±   0.079  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.different_datasets_with_similar_distributions  avgt    5      2.412 ¬±   0.070  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.groupByQuery                                   avgt    5      1.220 ¬±   0.117  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.long_chain                                     avgt    5    713.659 ¬±  19.454  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.lots_of_optional                               avgt    5    202.711 ¬±   5.901  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.minus                                          avgt    5  15092.775 ¬± 274.211  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.nested_optionals                               avgt    5    210.971 ¬±   6.627  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.pathExpressionQuery1                           avgt    5     19.107 ¬±   0.706  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.pathExpressionQuery2                           avgt    5      1.308 ¬±   0.087  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.query_distinct_predicates                      avgt    5     88.170 ¬±   3.452  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.simple_filter_not                              avgt    5     10.155 ¬±   0.581  ms/op
```

So there is a bunch of stuff in this branch now. I'll have to at least split things into separate commits. 

Comparing performance against the current state of the main branch is pretty cool. With all the performance improvements currently on develop together with the improvements in this branch the overall query performance is often around 2x better and more importantly a bit over 2x for concurrent queries.

I have long intended to create some reusable benchmarks so we can compare the NativeStore, LMDB Store and the MemoryStore. The overhead of disk access will probably reduce the performance impact, but there should still be some improvements. 

I also want to post some ShaclSail benchmarks, since the validation typically generates a lot of queries many of which take more time to optimize than to evaluate.
The benchmarks aren't accurate anymore since I split out the remainder of this PR into a separate branch: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3943

> I was thinking about doing some rewrites of those tests but was wondering if they are not published on maven? In which case others might be using them.

That's a good point - I may leave the old set of tests in (deprecated) purely for backward compatibility. They won't run if we don't have concrete implementations on our end, but other parties can continue using them.
Maybe ask around if anyone does? people can always continue to use the old test jars.

> Maybe ask around if anyone does? people can always continue to use the old test jars.

Unfortunately I've found in the past that "asking around" is not a very reliable system. People don't pay attention to that kind of stuff until they bump versions and suddenly stuff breaks.

In any case leaving the old tests in places in deprecated form is not a big chore, it's a single Java class after all :)

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3696  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

- fix in QueryJoinOptimizer to ensure it handles BIND arguments wrapped in e.g. a filter condition as priority arguments as well
- added compliance test
- small improvement in the optimizer pipeline: push filters down _before_ join optimization

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [x] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [x] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [x] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [x] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [x] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments: This test case should probably be moved into the SPARQL compliance tests. Related to this: #3926
Btw. I think that the reason the build doesn't fail is that the class name doesn't end in "test".

I think the core of the problem is in the `QueryJoinOptimizer`. The (optimized) query plan for the failing query is this:

```
Projection
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêProjectionElemList
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "bind"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "b1"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "n0"
‚ïë     ProjectionElem "n1"
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêJoin (JoinIterator)
   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄStatementPattern (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=1)
   ‚îÇ     Var (name=n0)
   ‚îÇ     Var (name=_const_1bf65419_uri, value=http://example.org/has, anonymous)
   ‚îÇ     Var (name=n1)
   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄExtension
      ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêJoin (JoinIterator)
      ‚ïë  ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄFilter (costEstimate=4, resultSizeEstimate=4)
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ  ‚ï†‚ïê‚ïêCompare (=)
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ  ‚ïë     Var (name=b1)
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ  ‚ïë     ValueConstant (value="Unit2")
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ  ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêStatementPattern (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=2)
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ        Var (name=bind)
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ        Var (name=_const_9285ccfc_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label, anonymous)
      ‚ïë  ‚îÇ        Var (name=b1)
      ‚ïë  ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄStatementPattern (costEstimate=1, resultSizeEstimate=2)
      ‚ïë        Var (name=bind)
      ‚ïë        Var (name=_const_f5e5585a_uri, value=http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type, anonymous)
      ‚ïë        Var (name=_const_62cbbc05_uri, value=http://example.org/Unit, anonymous)
      ‚ïö‚ïê‚ïêExtensionElem (n0)
            Var (name=bind)
```

The Join optimer pulls the `(n0, has, n1)` statement pattern forward (becaue it cheaper than the full Extension block), but in doing so it messes with  the variable scope: there is a hard requirement that the target variable of an extension can not have been used before.
Looks good.

Ok what the hell? 

This has started failing again after a rebase, and when trying to debug it appears it doesn't even pass through the QueryJoinOptimizer anymore.
@hmottestad why is there a duplicate QueryJoinOptimizer class?

@hmottestad it looks as if the optimizer classes were refactored into a new package (`org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.algebra.evaluation.optimizer`) but unfortunately the old classes were left in place as-is (instead of making them deprecated extensions). I'll do some cleanup.

I ended up duplicating a lot of the optimizers because I needed to change the super class (extends). I should have deprecated the original classes. I presume I forgot to update the tests to point to the new classes?

I'll open an issue for checking if I've deprecated all the classes and updated the tests. 

As for the discussion on backwards compatibility, I've not followed through with any changes based on that. I don't see a need for keeping binary compatibility for minor releases, only for bug fix releases. Would that make a difference in this case? 

Originally I also wanted to loosen up on some of the source compatibility restrictions for minor releases to allow me to change the super class for the optimizers instead of duplicating and deprecating. My rational was the there is a difference between class inheritance used for example with Value/Resource/IRI and inheritance used purely for DRY code. I didn't follow through with any changes based on this either.

Running all the benchmarks takes a really long time, so reduced I the number of iterations for each benchmark. That's why there are some benchmarks that seem to be significantly slower. I reran the ones that had gotten slower and they all look pretty much identical to the "before" numbers once they run them for more than a few iterations.

The goal of this PR was to improve the QualifiedValueShape benchmarks, which I succeeded in doing. Performance for that benchmark is now in line with the performance in RDF4J 4.0.0.

```
Benchmark                                      Score (before)    Score (after)   Units
QualifiedValueShapeBenchmarkEmpty.shacl             14618.53           7758.16   ms/op
```

At the moment I haven't found any existing benchmarks that are improved in this branch. The changes are based on my WIP performance branch #3854. Fixing one bottle neck will often reveal another performance issue that was masked by the initial bottle neck, so that might be the case here too. That being said there are quite a few fixes in that branch that didn't end up making much of a difference.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3902 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Original code first looked up all four S,P,O,C in the memory value factory before finding out what the smallest statement list size was. I rewrote it to look up one value at a time instead of all four at once, that way we could return earlier if the statement list size was 0. 

I forgot to take account of that the memory value factory returns null when the value is unknown, which entails that there can't be any statements with the value. Fixed that now.

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

----

Made changes in the ElasticSearchSailExample.java, it had multiple queries running in only one function, so to print runtime, i just calculated runtime for that only function which ran multiple queries together. 

Please point out if the way is wrong.

----

GitHub issue resolved: #2524

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

The handling of binding substitution fails for queries of the form select (func(?x) as ?y). For a binding x=foo the output is select (func('foo' as ?x) as ?y) when it should be select (func('foo') as ?y). The current code only works for select ?x ?y ?z type queries. Regex has been modified to ignore patterns that are preceded by 'as'.

----

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

* Help is welcome!
