comments:
After solving the `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException` issue, the code currently fails in `ValidationQuery.union()`, where the two ValidationQueries are checked in a number of assert statements. To see which queries are joined, we print them to stdout, here's the output:
```
union of a: 
?target_0000000000 a <https://mms.researchstudio.at/mms#EnumerationType> .
?target_0000000000 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .

FILTER(NOT EXISTS{?value <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .})
union of b: 
?target_0000000000 a <https://mms.researchstudio.at/mms#EnumerationType> .
?target_0000000000 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
?value_0 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
?value_1 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
FILTER(?value_0 != ?value_1)

union of a: 
{
?target_0000000000 a <https://mms.researchstudio.at/mms#EnumerationType> .
?target_0000000000 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .

FILTER(NOT EXISTS{?value <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .})
} UNION {
?target_0000000000 a <https://mms.researchstudio.at/mms#EnumerationType> .
?target_0000000000 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
?value_0 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
?value_1 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
FILTER(?value_0 != ?value_1)

}
union of b: 
?target_0000000000 a <https://mms.researchstudio.at/mms#EnumerationType> .
?target_0000000000 <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
?value <http://www.linkedmodel.org/schema/dtype#hasMember> ?target_0000000001 .
 FILTER(!(EXISTS{?value a <https://mms.researchstudio.at/mms#EnumerationType>}))
2022-05-10 17:24:47,556 [ForkJoinPool-1-worker-5] DEBUG org.eclipse.rdf4j.sail.shacl.ShaclSailConnection - Cleanup

java.lang.AssertionError
	at org.eclipse.rdf4j.sail.shacl.ast.ValidationQuery.union(ValidationQuery.java:84)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReduceOps$2ReducingSink.accept(ReduceOps.java:123)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$3$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:195)
  [...]
```

The problem seems caused by one of the value variables being called `value` whereas the other is `value_1`

@hmottestad I think we need your help here
Can't find the cause by our own and will wait now for @hmottestad or someone else who knows, why this happens here.

I've found the issue and I've tested a fix. Thanks for creating a test case. 

I would like to use your test case in my code, so if you could take a look at the contributor guide and make sure you have signed the Eclipse Contributor Agreement. That way I can merge your branch in with my fix. 

https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#legal-stuff

In short the issue is that some property shape constraints produce values and others don't. Min/max count don't, but class does. So it's correct that the index for the value is out of bounds. The problem here is that the use of sh:node stops the ShaclSail from splitting the shape into multiple shapes and then runs into the bug where the union code doesn't correctly check if the constraint produces a value or not.

And as a temporary fix you can disable SPARQL based validation, and revert to using the regular bulk or transactional validation for everything. This will make some validations slower. 

You can set the property `org.eclipse.rdf4j.sail.shacl.sparqlValidation` to the `false`. Both as strings. See https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/12/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/System.html#setProperty(java.lang.String,java.lang.String)
I've posted a PR here: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3877
Okay, thank you! I've signed the Eclipse Contributor Agreement and you can merge the test case as well.
Merged into [GH-3871-shacl-index-out-of-bounds](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/tree/GH-3871-shacl-index-out-of-bounds)

GitHub issue resolved: #3860 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
 - detect when there is less than 64MB of free RAM (with Xmx>=256MG) and stop releasing the write lock while running the snapshot cleanup in the MemoryStore
 - the snapshot cleanup process already tracks what it has already cleaned to improve performance, but the HashSets used for tracking are now clearer if we have little memory

comments: @jeenbroekstra it seems that new default methods in an interface are not binary compatible. We used to allow this for minor releases (eg. 4.1.0).
I think we need to have a wider discussion about what kind of compatibility we want to support. Possibly binary is not really preferred for minor releases in general, only for patches....
We can tweak this how we like, I just went with the defaults assuming that's reflecting the widest concensus on what SemVer entails.

At the moment I haven't found any existing benchmarks that are improved in this branch. The changes are based on my WIP performance branch #3854. Fixing one bottle neck will often reveal another performance issue that was masked by the initial bottle neck, so that might be the case here too. That being said there are quite a few fixes in that branch that didn't end up making much of a difference.

comments: @kenwenzel would you like to target this at the main branch? And if it is otherwise ready then I can review and merge it :)
Thank you for asking. It's ready and should also be targeted at main to get the store working with the RDF4J server.
Going to take a little bit of time to review this. You are introducing a new locking system that I need to try to understand.

@kenwenzel Have you considered using one of the existing lock managers? There are fast implementations of read-preferred and write-preferred locks, as well as a stamped lock. The benefit of these is that you can enable various levels of tracking, logging and automatic unlocking if the lock gets garbage collected.

@hmottestad The lock is a StampedLock and it existed already in the last version. Let me know if the other locks are faster. In this case we could simply switch to another implementation.

The lock is only required for autogrow to stop any read and write transactions while changing the map size.
https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/tree/main/core/sail/api/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/common/concurrent/locks

The ReadPrefReadWriteLockManager is faster than a plain stamped lock, but there is a small overhead because of the lock object. It uses a combination of a StampedLock and two LongAdders to achieve faster read locks than just using the StampedLock. I also intend to switch it over to using a boolean and VarHandle instead.

The biggest reason to use the lock managers is that they make debugging locking bugs easier because they can be configured to detect abandoned locks and also possible deadlocks. 

We use these for transaction management and iterators that are user facing. So that if a user forgets to close the iterator for a query result then the lock is automatically released when it becomes phantom reachable.

The current implementation uses only one lock instance for the whole triple store. The lock itself is acquired while fetching data within the iterators next() method and is released immediately afterwards. Therefore it cannot happen that the user forgets to free the lock. I am unsure if it is really helpful to use ReadPrefReadWriteLockManager in this case as the locks are very short-lived and also guaranteed to be freed.

In general you are referencing the stamped lock directly and not storing it in a variabel, except for here: [/LmdbRecordIterator.java#L117](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/7a14aed5bd751a851bc18bd9c239f7b3d50ca50e/core/sail/lmdb/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/sail/lmdb/LmdbRecordIterator.java#L117)

And here [LmdbRecordIterator.java#L100](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/7a14aed5bd751a851bc18bd9c239f7b3d50ca50e/core/sail/lmdb/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/sail/lmdb/LmdbRecordIterator.java#L100) there is some code between the read lock and the try/finally section which could potentially throw and exception so that the read lock doesn't get released.
@hmottestad @jeenbroekstra Should I rebase this against main?

> @hmottestad @jeenbroekstra Should I rebase this against main?

Yeah for a bug fix that's a good idea.
I've cherry picked your commit into this PR here to merge into main: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3883
Merged with https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3883

comments: Currently just updated benchmarks

### Before
```
Benchmark                                                    Mode  Cnt      Score   Error  Units
QueryWriteBenchmark.clear                                    avgt        4988.766          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearByQuery                             avgt        5098.125          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearByQueryReadCommitted                avgt        5087.286          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearContext                             avgt        5253.665          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearContextReadCommitted                avgt        5090.283          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearReadCommitted                       avgt        5251.581          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQuery                            avgt         683.343          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQueryReadCommitted               avgt       10929.772          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.simpleUpdateQueryIsolationNone           avgt        5946.747          ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.simpleUpdateQueryIsolationReadCommitted  avgt        5750.241          ms/op
```

### After
```
Benchmark                                                    Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
QueryWriteBenchmark.clear                                    avgt    3  1408.016 ¬± 410.591  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearByQuery                             avgt    3  1417.947 ¬± 161.125  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearByQueryReadCommitted                avgt    3  1443.085 ¬± 832.789  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearContext                             avgt    3  1484.507 ¬± 698.539  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearContextReadCommitted                avgt    3  1426.219 ¬± 559.098  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearReadCommitted                       avgt    3  1418.455 ¬± 482.580  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQuery                            avgt    3   225.014 ¬± 132.836  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQueryReadCommitted               avgt    3   394.238 ¬± 355.975  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.simpleUpdateQueryIsolationNone           avgt    3   287.107 ¬± 141.161  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.simpleUpdateQueryIsolationReadCommitted  avgt    3   414.085 ¬±  89.380  ms/op
```

### After (without the in-memory record cache)
```
Benchmark                                                    Mode  Cnt      Score       Error  Units
QueryWriteBenchmark.clear                                    avgt    3   2297.945 ¬± 10952.835  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearByQuery                             avgt    3   1778.247 ¬±   560.089  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearByQueryReadCommitted                avgt    3   1971.445 ¬±  5143.147  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearContext                             avgt    3   1787.650 ¬±    78.578  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearContextReadCommitted                avgt    3   1786.186 ¬±   168.237  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.clearReadCommitted                       avgt    3   1792.883 ¬±   918.566  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQuery                            avgt    3    264.565 ¬±    47.813  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQueryReadCommitted               avgt    3  11454.502 ¬±  5448.151  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.simpleUpdateQueryIsolationNone           avgt    3   6300.980 ¬±  1666.365  ms/op
QueryWriteBenchmark.simpleUpdateQueryIsolationReadCommitted  avgt    3   6037.938 ¬±   708.216  ms/op
```

Biggest difference is for `QueryWriteBenchmark.removeByQueryReadCommitted` which was creating a new cache file for every statement that it was going to remove!
Big question is if the memory based cache will affect integrity in case of something like a power outage. I don't think it will, but it's hard to be sure.

With 1GB as the limit for the benchmark we are always staying in memory. I want to post the results without the in-memory cache, since the various fixes for aligning to 4KB and doing read ahead also make a big difference.

> Big question is if the memory based cache will affect integrity in case of something like a power outage. I don't think it will, but it's hard to be sure.

The problem might be that a partially applied transaction cannot be rolled back when the record cache (some kind of WAL) is missing.

I can't see that it ever gets read back in again. 

The WAL seems to based on editing the B-tree and adding a flag to denote that a statement was removed or added. And then during commit the status file is updated to "committing" and each statement that is flagged for removal is removed and those flagged as added statements just have their flag cleared. 

During recovery the transaction status file is read and if it's in  the commit phase then it just resumes iterating over the statements and doing what the flag says. If it's not in the commit phase then it assumes that no action has been taken based on the flags and essentially just resets  them. 

The recovery mechanism just calls the commit and rollback methods. The updatedTriplesCache is used to track which statements have been updated during the transaction, so that commit and rollback only need to iterate over affected statements instead of all the statements. When the recovery mechanism invokes the commit and rollback methods there isn't an updatedTriplesCache so it instead needs to iterate over all the statements in the indexes. 

It looks like the updatedTriplesCache is kept in a specific file, but I can't see how it is used during recovery and it makes me wonder if it too could be  kept in memory.

@hmottestad Maybe  I am wrong but the potential problem arises if the record cache is kept in memory and the commit phase is interrupted (e.g. writing to disk failed). Then it is impossible to decide which statements were part of the unsuccessful transaction.

This is the code that handles marking a statement for removal. 

It's got three parts. 

The first part collects records (bytes) for each statement from the btree and stores them in a cache. 

Then it writes that cache into the transaction cache. (Which I'm unsure if really requires persistence). 

Then it loops through the first cache and writes to the btree. But it doesn't actually delete anything, just writes the record back with a modified flag to indicate that the statement should be deleted. 

Later on commit() is called and then the transaction cache is used to perform the actual deletes.

In its current implementation the transaction cache may also be incomplete. So it should not matter If you keep it in memory or not. Hence also with the current implementation it may happen that a transaction can not be completely rolled back if commit() fails and the cache is incomplete.
BTW, at this point the rollback is only required in case of an IO error as the base implementation of the SAIL already handles transactions.
Therefore it may even be possible to directly modify the b-tree without using the flags as intermediate step. But I'm unsure if this is even less safe than the current approach.

Edit: The flags are required to circumvent concurrent modification problems.
Flags also allow to perform a rollback from isolation level NONE.

GitHub issue resolved: #3811 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Ensure the now value is instantiated to the same value but lazily at a low cost.

----

 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made

comments: Why does it need to be thread safe?

Currently it doesn't. I just thought you wanted it to be threadsafe because in the Performance branch you used a synchronized block around it. I think it is a nice idea because it would be hard to other wise guarantee this once we do introduce a parallel query evaluation strategy.

Double checked locking might be simpler to understand and reason about. 

Or you can try out VarHandle. Allows you to do atomic compare and set. It's a bit overkill maybe, but super cool ü§§
@hmottestad if going for atomic's a simple AtomicReference will do, no need for varhandles.

I'm playing a bit with VarHandles here: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/1bb3e1efb967a8ea5a1d96d4153b56c0a218fe46/core/sail/nativerdf/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/sail/nativerdf/SequentialRecordCache.java

Essentially it allows a write-once value to be declared without volatile, but still do atomic compare and set as well as volatile reads. 

In my case I'm lazily initializing  a variable. If the variable is not null, then we can safely use. If it is null then it could either be uninitialized or a stale read. So then I do a volatile read to be sure it's not stale, and then if it's still null I initialize the variable using compare and set.

I don't think I'll keep this code. It's a bit overkill and I don't really need to lazily initialize the variable. I might pick it up again somewhere else where locking or synchronization adds a lot of overhead. 

Can I propose using volatile and double checked locking for your code? System.currentTimeMillis() is platform dependent and there used to be some issues with poor performance in Linux. https://www.mo4tech.com/cant-believe-it-system-currenttimemillis-has-a-performance-problem.html
On review I did now implement it with a varhandle. In retrospect I think this is the nicest and best solution with the lowest runtime impact.

Could you make some tests to cover this code? There is a query optimizer that rewrites calls to now() with a constant value, so I don't actually think we have any tests that cover this code path. You could try to just return `null` to see if there are any tests that fail.

I'm also going to start pushing out the 4.0.0 release, but since this is a minor bug fix we can target it towards 4.0.1.

@hmottestad thank you for the review as the code was quite broken :( I now added a number of tests and the code is now exercised correctly on this branch. (It would have executed on GH-3798-more-functions-precompiled)

@JervenBolleman is this PR ready to merge?
I need to double check the merge but otherwise this was ready to go.
@JervenBolleman this has been sitting for a while now - is all that's needed a rebase before it's ready to merge?
I rebased it and I think it is ready for a merge.

@JervenBolleman I'm sorry that we have to keep doing this, but it seems we missed the window to merge this, and it now has several conflicts again. Do you think you have time to try and resolve this? Would be ace if we could get this merged before a 4.3 release...
@abrokenjester no, problem :) I had actually done the work last night. Just had to check that mvn verify had passed this morning.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #1755  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

- parser/writer settings for binary, turtle, json-ld, rdf/sjon, and trix have been moved into their parser-specific packages/modules
- settings for n-triples and xml-based parsers/writers have been left as they are generically reused in several places

@barthanssens I'd like your thoughts on whether we really get any benefits of this change. I'm personally not 100% convinced it's the right thing to do.

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [ ] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [ ] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments: @hmottestad @JervenBolleman @aschwarte10 any of you have any opinions on this refactor? _If_ we want to do this, we should do it before 4.0.

I would really prefer to keep the merges to develop to bug fixes only since we are so close to releasing 4.0.0.

I haven't looked through your code though, so I don't know how big of a change this is. Could it be targeted at 4.1.0? Or maybe deprecate some stuff now so that it's easier to remove in 5.0.0?

I've got a lot of breaking changes in my performance branch, so I'm fairly eager to work towards 5.0.0 sooner rather than later.

It's package reshuffling, so kind of a pain to do in a minor release (you'd have to introduce deprecated duplicates of the moved classes in the old location, which is annoying when using code completion), but not impossible. But my main thing is really that I'm not convinced this refactor really gains us anything. The basic idea (have all parser-specific stuff in that parser's package/module instead of in the generic rio api module) is sound enough but it ignores the fact that a lot of this is still shared between multiple parser implementations.

And you're right: it's rather close to release. Perhaps it's better to just park this for now, then do a more comprehensive reorg (including some of the shared stuff) later, for 5.0.

GitHub issue resolved: #3789  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

<!-- short description of your change goes here -->
 - logging
 - support isolation level NONE
 - improve performance
 - fix flushing of inferred statements in the NativeStore
 - concurrent forward chaining

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3782  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

When a query has a GROUP BY clause, the projection may only contain:

 1. aggregate expressions
 2. constants
 3. simple expressions consisting of just a variable (if and only if that var is in the GROUP BY)

code changes: 

- check presence of all non-simple expression types in projeciton when using GROUP BY
- clearer errors are given
- added test cases

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [ ] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [ ] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments:
@aschwarte10 thanks for the feedback, and that additional query looks interesting. If you have the means, could you rewrite it to this and try it out:

```sparql
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> 
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX foaf: <http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/>
PREFIX dc: <http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/>
SELECT DISTINCT 
	?s (?o AS ?o1) 
	?o2
	(COUNT(DISTINCT ?p) AS ?count) 
	(rdf:type AS ?typeProperty) 
WHERE {
	{ 	
		?s ?p ?o . 
		?s rdf:type foaf:Person . 
		BIND ('42' AS ?knowsname ) . 
		?o rdf:type dc:Document . } 
	MINUS 
	{
			?s rdf:type rdfs:Resource . 
			OPTIONAL { ?s ?p ?o . } 
	} 
	FILTER (NOT EXISTS { ?s rdfs:label ?o }) 
} GROUP BY ?s ?o (<http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#boolean>(?o) AS ?o2) 
HAVING (?count=5) 
ORDER BY ?s ?o1 
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 5 
VALUES (?s) { (<http:example.org/dummy>) }
```

In other words: move the boolean cast to _inside_ the GROUP BY, and project the resulting alias (o2).
That should be syntactically fine, but if you can try I'd like to verify that it also gives the expected result when evaluated.

Regardless, I should probably have a quick look at our test suite to see if this  kind of thing is covered. Pretty sure it is, but never hurts to double-check.

@jeenbroekstra the parsing works good (which is what we are expecting with this change)

The query renderer in `org.eclipse.rdf4j.queryrender.sparql.experimental.SparqlQueryRenderer.SparqlQueryRenderer()` however seems to produce a slightly different query:

```
FILTER (!EXISTS {	?s <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label> ?o . } ) 
BIND (<http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#boolean>(?o)  AS ?o2) . 
 }
 GROUP BY ?s ?o ?o2
```

i.e. it moves the function call as a BIND into the WHERE clause

I think this should be fine though (and if at all it is orthogonal to this fix)

Ontotext extends this in their code base, but there are no extensions points and they end up replicating all our functionality in order to add support for some very minor modifications.

I should probably have marked this at WIP, since I've still got some work to do.
Fwiw had a glance through your changes sofar, and looks like a solid refactor to me. Some of this setup hasn't been touched in years, so high time someone took a duster through it :)
@jeenbroekstra if all the tests pass I intend to merge this and publish the milestone build tomorrow. Is that ok with you?
Sounds good to me!

GitHub issue resolved: #3737  <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Replace the use of of the `source` and `target` compiler arguments with the (new since Java 9) `release` argument. This will ensure that when we do 3.7.x releases, the produced artifacts will be compatible with Java 8 (even if the artifacts are compiled using a newer JVM).

A potential downside: this flag will cause an error if you are _actually_ using Java 8 to compile the code, as the `release` argument was only introduced in Java 9. However, given that we are all running more modern Javas on our machines, and that our Jenkins deployment jobs also have been configured to use Java 11, I think  this may be the simplest way to fix the issue.


See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43102787/what-is-the-release-flag-in-the-java-9-compiler

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [ ] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [ ] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments:
I overlooked that this will break our github actions.... We would need to tweak this using a profile to get it working. 

Alternatively, we just scratch this, and instead make sure that we use the Java 8 Jenkins jobs I created when doing 3.x releases (see comment on issue ticket).

I've been thinking a bit about this one. If we switch to java 9+ for GitHub CI we would be able to use the release flag to target java 8, but when running tests we would still be running them in a newer JVM. 

The release flag is definitely the way to go, since it also checks that all the java apis that are called form the code actually exist in the given version. 

I think we can set the release flag from the properties section, and then presumably from the command line or environment as well. Maybe we can tweak the GitHub CI to unset the release flag and instead set the source and target version instead?

> I've been thinking a bit about this one. If we switch to java 9+ for GitHub CI we would be able to use the release flag to target java 8, but when running tests we would still be running them in a newer JVM.
> 
> The release flag is definitely the way to go, since it also checks that all the java apis that are called form the code actually exist in the given version.
> 
> I think we can set the release flag from the properties section, and then presumably from the command line or environment as well. Maybe we can tweak the GitHub CI to unset the release flag and instead set the source and target version instead?

Possibly. I'm just on the fence if the effort is really worth it, given that we are close to getting 4.0 released. We're unlikely to do many more Java 8 releases.
I can possibly do something using maven profiles to handle this. Trying it out now.
This did the trick - happy with it. We'll need to be a little careful in the main->develop sync after this is merged to make sure develop config doesn't end up in a weird state.

comments:
This looks really interesting. I wasn't even aware that the annotation `org.osgi.annotation.bundle.Export` exists.

I just want to mention that it may also be possible to use a base `bnd.bnd` file with `-exportcontents` as we do in KOMMA:
https://github.com/komma/komma/blob/master/bnd.bnd

The individual properties can then be overwritten by specific `bnd.bnd` files within the modules:
https://github.com/komma/komma/blob/master/bundles/ui/net.enilink.commons.ui/bnd.bnd

Yes there are a lot of more powerful opportunities. But i would not push this project to hard and this is especially if most package-info.java files exist the best way.

Export-Package:  is the best way when using a bnd.bnd file.
But in this project layout most yould be done with annotations. 
Will show you in further commits.


There is an little issue in Handling war files so that the test will fail at ine Point but i am on fixings this.

I haven't tested your code yet but I have seen that you don't use the annotation `org.osgi.annotation.versioning.Version` to specify the package versions.
Are version numbers correctly added to the manifest by Bnd?

Spec:
```
The package must also be annotation with the [Version](https://osgi.github.io/osgi/core/framework.api.html#org.osgi.annotation.versioning.Version) annotation to specify the export version of the package.
```
https://osgi.github.io/osgi/core/framework.api.html#org.osgi.annotation.bundle.Export

But bnd takes the version from the bundle.
```
Export-Package: org.eclipse.rdf4j;uses:="org.eclipse.rdf4j.common.tran
 saction,org.eclipse.rdf4j.model";version="3.7.6",org.eclipse.rdf4j.ex
 ceptions;uses:="org.eclipse.rdf4j.common.annotation,org.eclipse.rdf4j
 .model";version="3.7.6",org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.datatypes;uses:="java
 x.xml.datatype,javax.xml.namespace,org.eclipse.rdf4j.model";version="
 3.7.6",org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.impl;uses:="javax.xml.datatype,org.ecl
 ipse.rdf4j.model,org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.base,org.eclipse.rdf4j.model
 .vocabulary";version="3.7.6",org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.util;uses:="java
 x.xml.datatype,org.eclipse.rdf4j,org.eclipse.rdf4j.common.annotation,
 org.eclipse.rdf4j.model,org.eclipse.rdf4j.model.vocabulary";version="
 3.7.6"
 ```

Thanks for submitting this @stbischof. Could you please also log an issue in our tracker that describes this enhancement, and link it to your PR? Also, given that this is an enhancement rather than a bug fix, if would be good if you could rebase this against the develop branch.
Marked this as stale to signal that the PR hasn't been active for a while and that we should consider closing it.
@laeubi could you take this?

> Export-Package: is the best way when using a bnd.bnd file.

I'm currently [adding support for `@Export` and `@Version` to PDE](https://github.com/eclipse-pde/eclipse.pde/issues/69) so soon there will be no excuse not to use these annotation everywhere :-)

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3720 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

It add parameters in the LuceneSail to filter the indexed element by languages and types.

- ``INDEXEDLANG``: Check when we are indexing a Literal that the language of the literal is one of the elements in the parameters. 
  Example: ``INDEXEDLANG=fr en`` to filter only French and English literals.
- ``INDEXEDTYPES``: Check for the triple (?s my:pred my:type) in the store or update query before adding an element to the store, my:pred and my:type can be configured. 
  Example:``INDEXEDTYPES="http\\://example.org/oftype=http\\://example.org/type1"``, will filter all the subjects ?s without the triple (?s http://example.org/oftype, http://example.org/type1) in the store or the query.

Another parameter ``INDEX_TYPE_BACKTRACE_MODE`` can be set with the method ``setIndexBacktraceMode(TypeBacktraceMode)`` to define how Lucene should handle the add and a remove of a type triple (?s my:pred my:type):

- ``TypeBacktraceMode.COMPLETE``: will check every triples with ?s and try to add or remove them in the Lucene Index
- ``TypeBacktraceMode.PARTIAL``: won't check previous triples in the store, assume that the user would add new elements to the index after and with the add of a type triple and would remove elements to the index with the remove of type.

----

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3711

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
When a request fails because the underlying connection was shut down on
the server due to inactivity only once a retry is attempted.

If the connection is not empty, the next connection from the pool will
be used for the retry. However, this connection can be older than the
idle threshold on the server too. In that case we need to clean up this
pooled connection as well and retry with another connection.

In the worst case the pool is full of connections that are already idled
out on the server. We then need to clean the pool and retry with a fresh
connection.

This is a follow up fix to #3699

----

 - [x] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments:
The problem appears to be multiple automorphisms in the data: there are several subgraphs that start and end with blank nodes which (almost) map 1:1 onto each other. The graph is not lean. This shouldn't be a problem in itself though.

Somewhat peculiar is that it seems to be related to the strength of the hashing function. We use a 128 bit hash (murmur3) to assign unique blank node labels. When I change that to a 256 bit hash (sha256) the bug no longer occurs.

I'm speculating that the problem has to do with how we combine multiple hashes to calculate unique values, and that there can happen a collission more frequently than anticipated when using a lower size for the hashes.

I've ran a few benchmarks to see if going to a stronger hash would mean a significant performance decrease: 

Using murmur3_128:

```
Benchmark                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
IsomorphicBenchmark.shacl                          avgt   10  3.408 ¬± 0.212  ms/op
IsomorphicBenchmark.shaclValidationReport          avgt   10  9.749 ¬± 0.387  ms/op
IsomorphicBenchmark.shaclValidationReport_changed  avgt   10  9.994 ¬± 0.514  ms/op
```

Using sha256:

```
Benchmark                                          Mode  Cnt   Score   Error  Units
IsomorphicBenchmark.shacl                          avgt   10   3.718 ¬± 0.168  ms/op
IsomorphicBenchmark.shaclValidationReport          avgt   10  10.669 ¬± 0.091  ms/op
IsomorphicBenchmark.shaclValidationReport_changed  avgt   10  10.717 ¬± 0.324  ms/op
```

It is (naturally) slightly slower, but not significantly so.
Is there no way to detect collisions and maybe resolve them or fail over to the legacy isomorphic algorithm?

> Is there no way to detect collisions and maybe resolve them or fail over to the legacy isomorphic algorithm?

No. Or rather: perhaps there is, but it would need significant investment of research and dev time, which I currently don't have. In the mean time, we need to put reliability over performance and merge this as a short term fix.

> > Is there no way to detect collisions and maybe resolve them or fail over to the legacy isomorphic algorithm?
> 
> No. Or rather: perhaps there is, but it would need significant investment of research and dev time, which I currently don't have. In the mean time, we need to put reliability over performance and merge this as a short term fix.

Just wondering if maybe there is some underlying issue that is causing collisions to be more frequent?

> > > Is there no way to detect collisions and maybe resolve them or fail over to the legacy isomorphic algorithm?
> > 
> > 
> > No. Or rather: perhaps there is, but it would need significant investment of research and dev time, which I currently don't have. In the mean time, we need to put reliability over performance and merge this as a short term fix.
> 
> Just wondering if maybe there is some underlying issue that is causing collisions to be more frequent?

Oh, yes, most likely. I suspect that it has to do with how we calculate combined hashes. I _think_ we're following the letter of the algorithm as outlined in the technical paper there, but perhaps I've missed something. Certainly, in theory 128 bits should be enough to not cause collisions in graphs of this size (or any practical size, really). Yet clearly we do get a collision of sorts, and clearly using a larger hash size mitigates the issue. Perhaps there's an overflow in the hash combination algorithm that makes it collapse to a smaller value space? The trouble is that I can't quite put my finger on it, and I've not been able to reduce the example - as soon as I take even a few triples out the isomorphism consistently succeeds.

You're good to merge this as is. 

Could you file a follow up issue though to look into the collisions? Maybe something along the lines of hashing with both murmur and sha to try to find out exactly where the collision is occurring.

> You're good to merge this as is.
> 
> Could you file a follow up issue though to look into the collisions? Maybe something along the lines of hashing with both murmur and sha to try to find out exactly where the collision is occurring.

Yep good point, will do.
commit_messages: GH-3671 use strong hash function to avoid collission

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3698

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Add a retry strategy for `408` responses from HTTP server. A server may -
instead of silently closing a connection - send a `408` response to the next
request after the idle timeout. The retry handler will retry the request with a
refreshed connection after receiving a `408`. It tries this exactly once. The
`408` is hence gracefully handled by default instead of erroring out.

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
 - StrictEvaluationStrategy no longer registers with the EvaluationStrategies cache
 - EvaluationStrategies deprecated since it was only used for registering StrictEvaluationStrategy and never for retrieving a registered/cached instance for deserialization
 - Make getUUID() late binding in StrictEvaluationStrategy and also deprecated

comments: Pity that this passes. That means we don't have any tests that cover the registration of evaluation factories :(

If I remember correctly this cache was added to aid on-disk overflow using MapDB of query results/iterations. This uses Java object serialization but we can't serialize the strategy object itself, so its use as a field on serializable objects was declared transient and retrieved from the cache upon deserialization - specifically in the OrderComparator. See https://bitbucket.org/openrdf/sesame/commits/8efdaed81ec6f969c15e28f029d7364e6236f2a5 .

As far as I can tell that use case is still there. I'll try and look at this in more detail over the weekend but unless I missed something this PR will break MapDB on-disk overflow of iterations in query evaluation. Clearly we haven't got this test-covered properly :(

It's no longer used. 

It's in use on the main branch:

https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/b5f9e4c5aca5d41b7c4207e09ca743c38e47e500/core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/util/OrderComparator.java#L144

But not on the develop branch: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/develop/core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/util/OrderComparator.java

> It's no longer used.
> 
> It's in use on the main branch:
> 
> https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/b5f9e4c5aca5d41b7c4207e09ca743c38e47e500/core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/util/OrderComparator.java#L144
> 
> But not on the develop branch: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/develop/core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/util/OrderComparator.java

Interesting! I hadn't seen that yet - must have overlooked in the PRs dealing with various changes. 

In that case there's no reason to keep this I guess.

I've figured this out. The pre-compilation that @JervenBolleman introduced means that we don't need to have a reference to the evaluation strategy anymore. So this is safe to merge. 

Another question I ran into was why the OrderComparator needs to be serializable at all? I can't see why we would need to serializable what is essential the evaluation plan for a query. I understand that we use serializable to spill to disk, but I don't understand why we want to spill OrderComparator to disk. The  order iteration (or something like that) spills its BindingSets to disk, presumably to not run out of memory when sorting a large amount of data.

> I've figured this out. The pre-compilation that @JervenBolleman introduced means that we don't need to have a reference to the evaluation strategy anymore. So this is safe to merge.
> 
> Another question I ran into was why the OrderComparator needs to be serializable at all? I can't see why we would need to serializable what is essential the evaluation plan for a query. I understand that we use serializable to spill to disk, but I don't understand why we want to spill OrderComparator to disk. The order iteration (or something like that) spills its BindingSets to disk, presumably to not run out of memory when sorting a large amount of data.

I was thinking the same thing, to be honest - it may have been a side effect of something that we already changed a long time ago.

GitHub issue resolved: #3665

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

In the project that contributed `rdf4j-spring`, we still haven't been able to switch to the 4.0.0 milestone, and we've had some minor changes to our rdf4j-spring code that we'd like to contribute - also with the goal to switch to the rdf4j implementation soon.

The changes are:

* handle the case of a  lost WeakReference in the ClearableAwareUpdate gracefully
* minor convenience changes
* provide helpful log output if a commit fails in a ShaclSail 
* enforce read-only behaviour in transactions explicitly marked read-only

comments: Work in progress!

### TODO
 - [x] make a new test case in ShaclTest that puts the shapes in a named graph and adds a `sh:shapesGraph` statement
 - [x] make test cases for union of multiple shape graphs with single datagraph
 - [ ] make test cases for multiple datagraphs
 - [x] add a config param to list all named graphs with shapes
 - [x] check current benchmarks and create new benchmarks so it becomes obvious what the cost of retrieving shapes from the base sail is
 - [x] look into caching of the shapes
 - [x] support implicit `sh:targetClass`
 - [ ] add documentation about how `sh:shapesGraph` and the new config option works and also about the use of `rdf4j:nil` for default graph
 - [x] add documentation about how the old `rdf4j:SHACLShapeGraph` uses the union of graphs
 - [x] reverse the cache refresh mechanism so that the next transaction refreshes the cache, in case the current transaction is interrupted

@jeenbroekstra and @barthanssens this PR is massive and I don't expect you to read through everything. I've made some comments to highlight some of the changes that might be worth looking at. In the beginning I created support for allowing shapes to be stored in any graph, then later I added a config option where the graphs have to be listed. During this time I found out that I would run out of memory with some of my multithreaded stress tests that used SERIALIZABLE isolation. This led me to optimize the ChangeSet implementation and fix some bugs where change sets where closed too early or not closed at all. This could be extracted into it's own PR with it's own issue if you guys think it's strictly necessary.

Thanks @hmottestad , looks impressive. I'll try and review in a bit more depth this weekend. Don't know yet if you should break into separate PRs, but it would be good if you could at least clean up the commit history a bit.

My browser crashes when trying to open the "Files changed" view. I can't verify, but I suspect that a large part of why this touches so many files is that you made fixes in cross-cutting concerns like the locking and ChangeSet implementations. It might be good to separate those out - both from a review perspective as well as a way for us to keep track of what changed for which reasons.

> My browser crashes when trying to open the "Files changed" view. I can't verify, but I suspect that a large part of why this touches so many files is that you made fixes in cross-cutting concerns like the locking and ChangeSet implementations. It might be good to separate those out - both from a review perspective as well as a way for us to keep track of what changed for which reasons.

The reason for all the changed files is because the entire shacl test suite was migrated from turtle to trig.

> > My browser crashes when trying to open the "Files changed" view. I can't verify, but I suspect that a large part of why this touches so many files is that you made fixes in cross-cutting concerns like the locking and ChangeSet implementations. It might be good to separate those out - both from a review perspective as well as a way for us to keep track of what changed for which reasons.
> 
> The reason for all the changed files is because the entire shacl test suite was migrated from turtle to trig.

Is that perhaps a thing you can separate out? If we can get that merged separately, it'll make it a lot easier to review the actual meat of the code changes.
It's a bit hard. The feature is support for shapes in named graphs, which is why I had to migrate to trig.
But I'll split out the non-SHACL stuff.
Ah good point, hadn't thought of that. Yeah let's split out the non shacl stuff and ill try to get a sense of the rest by checking out the branch and reading your comments here.

> Ah good point, hadn't thought of that. Yeah let's split out the non shacl stuff and ill try to get a sense of the rest by checking out the branch and reading your comments here.

body:
Remove setting of PRESERVE_BNODE_IDS parameter to true when a remote transaction is created. So when data is added to transaction the parser will use the default value of the parameter which is false and will create new identifiers to ensure uniqueness of blank nodes across multiple files.
If preserveNodeId parameter of HttpServletRequest is set to true, PRESERVE_BNODE_IDS will be reconfigured and bnode ids will be preserved.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3483 

- remove deprecate FedXConfig#setFedXConfig (to specify a location)
- fix use of supplied strategy factory in FederationManager (we need to
use the factory that is available in the federation instead of creating
a new one)
- refine FedXRepositoryWrapper for slightly better extensibility
(use-case: support fine-tuning the FedXFactory without requiring to
overwrite the entire file. Note that this is now required because the
evaluationstrategy can no longer be influenced through the FedXConfig)

comments:
I got curious about LMDB because of this implementation, and it seems client-side caching is not required because lookups are so fast. If you don't mind me asking: Is the value cache really needed? It could actually slow things down or become a bottleneck due to locking...

For example, https://github.com/lmdbjava/lmdbjava states as one important advantage of LMDB: "Freedom from application-side data caching (memory-mapped files are more efficient)".

@fkleedorfer This is an interesting question and not easy to answer.
LMDB is fast if the relevant pages can be kept in memory which is the case when your db's size is not very larger than the available RAM size.
Furthermore, when searching for a value the RDF4J LMDB store first needs to convert it to a byte array and then uses this byte array as key for the lookup.
This conversion involves memory allocations and multiple operations for translating the data. Due to the B+-Tree the lookup within LMDB also has the complexity of log(n).
I also think that locking may not be an issue because the caches are using ConcurrentHashMap that relies on multiple locks (> 16) for different hash segments.

Nevertheless, it may be worth to test the performance of the LMDB store without caching to finally answer your question.

comments:
The following benchmarks were run on a VM with networked storage (HDD RAID).
The performance of larger transactions increases by up to 50%.
Only the smallest transactions with one statement per transaction loose some performance by around 5 - 10%.

```
# w/o multi-threading

TransactionsPerSecondBenchmark.transactions                    thrpt    5   9973.476 ¬± 207.579  ops/s
TransactionsPerSecondBenchmark.transactionsLevelNone           thrpt    5  17916.608 ¬± 297.140  ops/s

# w multi-threading

TransactionsPerSecondBenchmark.largerTransactionLevelNone      thrpt    5     49.999 ¬±   4.165  ops/s
TransactionsPerSecondBenchmark.mediumTransactionsLevelNone     thrpt    5  11947.161 ¬± 412.982  ops/s
TransactionsPerSecondBenchmark.transactions                    thrpt    5   9421.710 ¬± 260.423  ops/s

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3587 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

 - create an enum for all the core datatypes without depending on any vocabularies (like XSD.Datatype does)
     - also include rdf:langString
     - includes all the methods from XSD.Datatype
     - also has a bunch of other helper methods and a cache implementation to simplify implementation for us
 - add method to Literal interface to return an Optional<CoreDatatype>
     - this method is not allowed to return null and if it returns an empty optional then that is because the datatype is note one of the XSD datatypes or rdf:langString
 - implemented the new method in our code
 
The next step would be to take advantage of the new datatype enum throughout our code base to simplify and speed the places where we check the datatype against either rdf:langString or one of the XSD datatypes.


<!-- short description of your change goes here -->

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

comments: @jeenbroekstra @JervenBolleman @aschwarte10 @barthanssens @rdstn What do you guys think about my approach to having an enum for all the core literal datatypes? I really believe that this will allow us to simplify and optimize a lot of our code that depends on checking datatypes.
@hmottestad I think this reads nice and clean :) and looks like an improvement. Is it worth adding the GeoSPARQL datatype as well?

> @hmottestad I think this reads nice and clean :) and looks like an improvement. Is it worth adding the GeoSPARQL datatype as well?

I hadn't thought about those. I can see that geo:wktLiteral is used a fair bit. Any other that we should include?
@jeenbroekstra I have created an interface with three inner classes for the three datatype namespaces. What do you think?

I want to test out dropping the use of optional. Instead of retuning null though I thought we should return a fixed enum to indicate that the datatype is not a core datatype. 

This would be for performance. If it's not really faster then I think we should stick to optional.

GitHub issue resolved: #3589 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

 - cache the results of toString() using a soft reference to reduce the number of times we need to recompute it
    - typically the .toString() method is called when retrieving the MemIRI from MemValueFactory with an AbstractIRI because the .equals() method there uses the full string representation instead of the namespace and local name like MemIRI does.

Todo:
 - [ ] document changes to the interface in the release notes

## OOMBenchmark

Benchmark that uses the no-op Epsilon GC to measure how many times an operation can be run before running out of memory. 

### Before
```
OOMBenchmark.sortAllObjectsWithSparql:    Count:  2
OOMBenchmark.sortDirectly:                Count:  3
```

### After
```
OOMBenchmark.sortAllObjectsWithSparql:    Count: 11
OOMBenchmark.sortDirectly:                Count: 74
```


## SortBenchmark

I modified this benchmark (both before and after) to use the Serial GC to make it more obvious how much garbage (allocated memory that will be freed later) we are producing. This is the worst case scenario, since the Serial GC is a stop-the-world GC that uses a single thread. 

### Before
```
Benchmark                        Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
SortBenchmark.sortByQuery        avgt    5  4738.152 ¬± 319.567  ms/op
SortBenchmark.sortDirectly       avgt    5   449.743 ¬±   9.753  ms/op
SortBenchmark.sortGetStatements  avgt    5   459.508 ¬±  20.520  ms/op
```

### After
```
Benchmark                        Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units

SortBenchmark.sortDirectly       avgt    5   120.725 ¬±   1.212  ms/op
SortBenchmark.sortGetStatements  avgt    5   159.130 ¬±   5.239  ms/op
```

SortBenchmark.sortGetStatements  avgt    5  224.135 ¬±  5.552  ms/op
```
Yeah. It can, but this branch is a bit faster for the "direct" benchmark which is a bit odd. Would be nice to know the difference, so I'll keep it around for just a bit longer.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3574

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

Implement GC algorithm for values in LMDB store.
The algorithm will work synchronously to the transactions and will do the following work:
- track subject, predicate, object and context IDs when statements are removed from the triple indexes
- before finally committing a transaction:
  - test tracked IDs against the triple indexes and remove IDs which are still in use
  - add remaining IDs to some kind of "recycle" list within the value store and remove the associated data

----

@kenwenzel this PR has been sitting in draft state for a while now. Any chance you can take a look at getting it finalized?

@jeenbroekstra Thank you for the reminder.
My challenge is to decide what to do with the unused values:
1. directly delete them including their IDs
2. add them to a to-be-deleted list which is processed in a certain time interval (like every X seconds)

Option 1 is simple but prevents the direct reuse of values which are deleted and inserted again in a short period of time.
Option 2 enables the reuse of values but is a bit more complex to implement because it requires another LMDB table for tracking the deleted IDs.
@kenwenzel my 2 cents would be to go for the simple option, get that out, and then we can try and collect data on how much of an improvement a attempt at option 2 might be...

Option 2 is (almost) implemented.

- use persistent hash set to keep track of unused IDs during transaction

I'm wondering about what the use of commit and fsync are. I have a couple of questions:
 1. Does unusedIds get repopulated from disk at startup?
 2. Does it matter if some IDs are missing from unusedIds after a crash?
 3. Will another thread be able to read stale data from unusedIds if commit or fsync are not used, or is this guaranteed by LMDB or maybe the OS level filesystem cache?
 4. Does LMDB guarantee that the backing file(s) will never get corrupted if commit or fsync is omitted? (for instance by using an append only log so that a corrupted indexes can be rebuilt to a known good state, even though data could be lost due to the lack of fsync)

> 1. Does unusedIds get repopulated from disk at startup?
> 2. Does it matter if some IDs are missing from unusedIds after a crash?
> 3. Will another thread be able to read stale data from unusedIds if commit or fsync are not used, or is this guaranteed by LMDB or maybe the OS level filesystem cache?
> 4. Does LMDB guarantee that the backing file(s) will never get corrupted if commit or fsync is omitted? (for instance by using an append only log so that a corrupted indexes can be rebuilt to a known good state, even though data could be lost due to the lack of fsync)

1. No, it is just a temporary set used within ONE transaction.
2. They don't get GCed. But as unusedIds is only temporary this should not matter here at all.
3. The set is only accessed by the writing thread. I am not sure if PersistentSet is fully thread-safe at all as a LMDB write transaction would be handed over between multiple threads. (This seems to be allowed but I am not sure.)
4. Please see "MDB_NOSYNC" at http://www.lmdb.tech/doc/group__mdb.html#ga32a193c6bf4d7d5c5d579e71f22e9340
   LMDB claims to be very safe in this regard. But I also read that someone has managed to corrupt the underlying LMDB of the Monero blockchain...
   Maybe it would be good to use some threshold here and sync from time to time to disk as it is done by the MapDB-backed set. The same thing applies to the LMDB-based triple and values stores themselves.

Yes, but SnapshotSailStore makes sure that only one writer is active at any time. The transactions are completely serialized.

@hmottestad It would also be possible to not permanently share the set in a member variable but it might have a performance impact. AFAIK, I should be right and there is only one active writer at a time when using the SnapshotSailStore. Or am I wrong?
I don't know. I thought I would add some thread tracking code to your branch just to see if I can find any issues.

> I don't know. I thought I would add some thread tracking code to your branch just to see if I can find any issues.

Maybe this is not necessary. Both, NativeStore and LmdbStore rely on the fact that there is only a single writer thread for the backing store at a particular point in time. Concurrent writes would break the whole write logic of the value and triple stores.

I think it's the fork and sink design that is responsible for making sure that there is only a single writer that is using the main store. 

I did some more testing and couldn't get it to break. 

So this PR is good to merge!

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3572 <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
 - use an array of WeakHashMap objects to allow multithreaded access for both read and writes
     - we mod the hash of the key to index into the array
     - initial size of a WeakHashMap is 16 and we create `Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors() * 2` maps
         - this gives some overhead for MemoryStores with very very few values
         - as the maps fill up there should be less and less overhead since we are storing the same number of objects in total
 - use StampedLocks to allow multiple readers and single writer per WeakHashMap
     - this allows multiple writers if we hit different WeakHashMaps
 - remove external synchronization
 - use lambdas to support "getOrAdd" operations against the WeakObjectRegistry
 - deprecate three methods that are not thread-safe and create new methods that are thread-safe to achieve the same goal

QueryBenchmark.long_chain                                     avgt    5    943.471 ¬±   39.572  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.lots_of_optional                               avgt    5    265.192 ¬±   13.573  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.minus                                          avgt    5  12947.266 ¬± 4632.166  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.nested_optionals                               avgt    5    261.851 ¬±    7.480  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.pathExpressionQuery1                           avgt    5     22.891 ¬±    0.365  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.pathExpressionQuery2                           avgt    5      1.715 ¬±    0.049  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.query_distinct_predicates                      avgt    5    163.690 ¬±    1.847  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.simple_filter_not                              avgt    5     11.227 ¬±    2.106  ms/op
```

### Before
```
Benchmark                    (isolationLevel)  Mode  Cnt    Score    Error  Units
NotifyingSailBenchmark.load              NONE  avgt    5  141.340 ¬±  8.164  ms/op
NotifyingSailBenchmark.load          SNAPSHOT  avgt    5  181.063 ¬± 24.506  ms/op
NotifyingSailBenchmark.load      SERIALIZABLE  avgt    5  354.945 ¬± 30.844  ms/op
```

### After
```
Benchmark                    (isolationLevel)  Mode  Cnt    Score   Error  Units
NotifyingSailBenchmark.load              NONE  avgt   10  149.681 ¬± 8.608  ms/op
NotifyingSailBenchmark.load          SNAPSHOT  avgt   10  194.053 ¬± 1.590  ms/op
NotifyingSailBenchmark.load      SERIALIZABLE  avgt   10  343.319 ¬± 3.248  ms/op
```
So this is adding a small overhead when loading data into a MemoryStore. I'll investigate.

### Before
```
Benchmark                                      Mode  Cnt    Score    Error  Units
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.onlyReads   avgt    5  450.121 ¬± 78.835  ms/op
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.onlyWrites  avgt    5  749.964 ¬± 62.857  ms/op
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.readHeavy   avgt    5  217.716 ¬± 11.002  ms/op
```

### After
```
Benchmark                                      Mode  Cnt    Score    Error  Units
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.onlyReads   avgt    5   75.562 ¬±  1.790  ms/op
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.onlyWrites  avgt    5  416.135 ¬± 16.399  ms/op
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.readHeavy   avgt    5   83.085 ¬±  0.777  ms/op
```

The last benchmarks are specifically designed to show the performance improvements with this PR. That benchmark has three benchmarks that simulate various access patterns against the MemValyeFactory using multiple threads. The other benchmarks I've posted are just to show that there is no significant performance degradation for queries or when adding data.

Due to other bottlenecks in the system there is little performance improvements elsewhere due to this patch. One of those bottlenecks is locking, which I'm trying to address in the following PR: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3564

```
Benchmark                                      Mode  Cnt    Score   Error  Units
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.onlyReads   avgt   10   77.343 ¬± 0.272  ms/op
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.onlyWrites  avgt   10  437.942 ¬± 3.844  ms/op
MemValueFactoryConcurrentBenchmark.readHeavy   avgt   10   84.729 ¬± 0.071  ms/op
```

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #3483 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

(NOTE: it is recommended to do any review commit wise, as this is much easier to follow)

Commit 1: GH-3483: refactor federation execution to use a per-query strategy

This change refactors the execution of federated queries to use a
per-query instance of the FederationEvaluationStrategy.

The instance is passed via the QueryInfo object, which is already
specific to a given query execution.

Note that as a next step a proper factory mechanism needs to be put in
place in FederationManager and FederationContext (i.e. this change is
only the preparation, and it in fact still uses the same instance of the
strategy).


Commit 2: GH-3483: instantiate federation strategy through a factory

Adjust the federation initialization to use a proper
FederationEvaluationStrategyFactory for instantiating the actual
strategy.

Note that the SourceSelectionCache is now managed in the
FederationContext (to make it reusable across query executions)


Commit 3: GH-3483: make the Federation Strategy Factory configurable

This change allows to supply a custom FederationEvaluationStrategy
through the FedXFactory.

The previous mechanism of defining the class names trough the FedXConfig
and using reflection for instantiation is removed. A corresponding note
is added to the changelog


Commit 4: GH-3483: make federation write strategy configurable through FedXFactory

The WriteStrategyFactory is now configurable through the FedXFactory.
This avoids use of reflection (as previously done in FedXConfig)



----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

body:
Resolves GH-3558

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

- Reimplement the two basic LockManagers with StampedLock
- Reimplement read/write locks using a combination of StampedLock and LongAdder from: http://concurrencyfreaks.blogspot.com/2013/09/combining-stampedlock-and-longadder-to.html?m=1



----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

 - [ ] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
 - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
 - [ ] I've applied [code formatting](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-formatting) (you can use `mvn process-resources` to format from the command line)
 - [ ] I've [squashed](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/squashing) my commits where necessary 
 - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
comments:
Benchmarking locking is really hard. I've tried to create some benchmarks that combine various locking/releasing patterns back to back. The best benchmarks are those that do real world things and measure just the overhead that locking adds, but those are hard to create. In the SHACL benchmarks we have `ComplexLargeBenchmark.noPreloadingNonEmptyParallel` which is a decent benchmark that shows some of this overhead, but I don't know how to isolate the overhead other than to profile the running code. So that leaves us with the benchmarks I've created here for now.


### Before

```
Benchmark                                                Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixed                      avgt    5  4.820 ¬± 0.548  ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixedReadHeavy             avgt    5  4.566 ¬± 0.011  ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyReadLocksNoContention  avgt    5  4.425 ¬± 0.021  ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyWriteLocks             avgt    5  1.814 ¬± 0.052  ms/op
```

### After

```
Benchmark                                                Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixed                      avgt   10  0.614 ¬± 0.026  ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixedReadHeavy             avgt   10  0.535 ¬± 0.041  ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyReadLocksNoContention  avgt   10  1.709 ¬± 0.034  ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyWriteLocks             avgt   10  0.112 ¬± 0.002  ms/op
```

Since the WeakObjectRegistry now supports concurrent reads (and writes for that matter) we can now better see the overhead that the old LockManager code was causing. The new locks don't implement all the tracking that the old locks had, so it's not apples to apples at the moment, but the difference in performance is quite stark with more than a 2x improvement with a mixed read-only query load.

## Before

```
Benchmark                             Mode  Cnt    Score    Error  Units
ParallelQueryBenchmark.mixedWorkload  avgt    3  398.387 ¬± 89.162  ms/op
```

## After

```
Benchmark                             Mode  Cnt    Score    Error  Units
ParallelQueryBenchmark.mixedWorkload  avgt    3  151.281 ¬± 21.076  ms/op
```

@jeenbroekstra So I've still got some tests to figure out. Essentially just an issue with differences in performance of my machine vs the CI server. Might move those tests into a benchmark or something instead. 

Performance in general though is much improved with this new way of locking. I've still got some work to do on updating all the java docs and comments, but it would be great if you could take another look at this and maybe give it a try on your own machine if you have a chance.
It's a bit tricky to get the right balance of read priority vs write priority.

All the tests are passing now and I'm generally happy with the code.  I've also fixed a bunch of the java docs and updated the copy right headers and authors where I've essentially replaced the all the code. 

Would be nice to have some mixed read/write benchmarks to check that kind of performance too. At the moment I've just done benchmarks directly on the overhead of the locks and on concurrent read operations against the MemoryStore. 

TODO
- [x]  clean up commits by moving benchmarks to a single commit at the start of the branch, squash the rest of the commits

## Before

```
Benchmark                                                Mode  Cnt    Score
ParallelQueryBenchmark.mixedWorkload                     avgt   10  400.333 ms/op
```

```
Benchmark                                                Mode  Cnt    Score
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixed                      avgt    2    6.248 ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixedReadHeavy             avgt    2    5.352 ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyReadLocksNoContention  avgt    2    4.386 ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyWriteLocks             avgt    2    2.287 ms/op
```

## After

```
Benchmark                                                Mode  Cnt    Score
ParallelQueryBenchmark.mixedWorkload                     avgt   10  133.809 ms/op
```

```
Benchmark                                                Mode  Cnt    Score
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixed                      avgt    2    0.703 ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.mixedReadHeavy             avgt    2    0.677 ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyReadLocksNoContention  avgt    2    2.187 ms/op
ReadWriteLockManagerBenchmark.onlyWriteLocks             avgt    2    0.198 ms/op
```
**3x improvement to concurrent queries against the MemoryStore** (on my machine).

`QueryBenchmark.complexQuery` is the main target of this optimization, and it's greatly improved (almost 10x). ~~`QueryBenchmark.pathExpressionQuery1` is somewhat slower which I will have to investigate.~~
Also need to benchmark what cost this has for write operations.
What happens if to queries run in parallel and access the same iterator?
It's not the actual iterator that is cached, but an ArrayList with the results from the iterator. So if two threads both hit the cache then they will each get a new iterator backed by the list.

body:
GitHub issue resolved: #2741 

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

This is a clean series of commits that implement a query pre-compilation step. For each phase of the query evaluation we attempt to resolve all "constants for the life time of the query" and use them in java lamba's to do the actual evaluation.

It does so by introducing query evaluation steps. These are constructed once for the query and do the actual evaluation.
This logic allows us to reuse objects like lamba's which are relatively expensive to construct per invocation but should only be created once per query evaluation. For example we can now construct a near space optimal ArrayBindingSet, where we use lamba's to change lookups into direct index based array accesses.

This is the foundational feature with more improvements coming after it.

----
PR Author Checklist (see the [contributor guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details):

QueryBenchmark.complexQuery                             avgt    5    28.191 ¬±   4.948  ms/op

QueryBenchmark.groupByQuery                             avgt    5    11.154 ¬±   0.697  ms/op
QueryBenchmark.removeByQuery                            avgt    5   263.245 ¬±  36.484  ms/op

```

```

Benchmark                                               Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units

```

Findings: Most benchmarks are faster but especially groupByQuery is much slower. 
The removeX benchmarks have a lower fluctuation in runtime while the fluctuation of runtime for the simpleUpdateX
benchmarks increased. Maybe this is due to cache cleanups or other GC operations?!

Note: The benchmarks are executed on a Surface Book 3 with Linux in a Virtual Box VM that runs on Windows with anti virus software ü§£ This may also be the source for the observed fluctuations in runtime.

The "group by issue" seems to also persist for more complex queries.

I've used similar data and a comparable query that I've found within this conversation:
https://phabricator.wikimedia.org/T291903

@JervenBolleman Do you have any idea what could be the reason for slower group by evaluations?

https://github.com/kenwenzel/rdf4j/tree/complex-benchmark-GH-2741
```
# lmdb-lazy + GH-2741-queryevaluation-precompile

https://github.com/kenwenzel/rdf4j/tree/complex-benchmark
```

QueryBenchmarkComplex.queryPersonsSorted  avgt    5  6823.772 ¬± 2044.730  ms/op
```

Your new implementation shows 2 dominant execution paths in VisualVM:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/177272/146378921-6099d6dd-7ae9-4b09-b0b2-3ebe91ba8bac.png)

The "old" implementation has only one execution path:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/177272/146379037-42d0ef5c-168b-45c6-9b1a-097fd5ebefa3.png)

Have you changed anything within the stream implementation?

@kenwenzel yes. I have a good idea why the group by iterators slow down. The commit for that is by itself quite large and I haven't fully tested it. But I think I will add it to this one. Basically in group by we ended up building a lot of lamba's per final binding set, this is a lot of overhead.

So a basic query like
```sparql
SELECT COUNT(?s) WHERE {?s ?p ?o}
```
was sped up.
but a query like
```sparql
SELECT ?o COUNT(?s) WHERE {?s ?p ?o} GROUP BY ?o
```
was slowed down a lot.

We should try some queries with a lot of effective joins, since the usual procedure for a join operation is to create one iterator for the left side and for each returned element create a new iterator binding that element. So I'm wondering if this will end up calling the precompile stage for every new iterator it retrieves.

Could it be also the case that the query is evaluated twice for some reason? The two execution paths shown by VisualVM look suspicious.
I will check this tomorrow.

It's not two threads. You can see that one of the stack traces shows `GroupIterator <init>`, which is when a `new` GroupIterator is being instantiated. This iterator is then being used again in the stack trace that starts with the stream `count()` call.

> We should try some queries with a lot of effective joins, since the usual procedure for a join operation is to create one iterator for the left side and for each returned element create a new iterator binding that element. So I'm wondering if this will end up calling the precompile stage for every new iterator it retrieves.

No this should not be the case. On creation of the join evaluation step bot the left and right sides of the joins are prepared. This prepared step for the right is then invoked to generate the new iterators for each "joining".

See [JoinQueryEvaluationStep](core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/impl/evaluationsteps/JoinQueryEvaluationStep.java) and the [JoinIterator](core/queryalgebra/evaluation/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/query/algebra/evaluation/iterator/JoinIterator.java) look for `rightIter = preparedRight.evaluate(leftIter.next());`

A funny thing about the complexquery benchmark on the memory store is that it very consistent but slower in performance on this branch then on develop. Yet, the first few executions on develop are 20% slower than it's steady state.

...

# Warmup Iteration   8: 80.852 ms/op

```
Still this is not so great so I do need to have a look at why things.

@JervenBolleman the complexQuery benchmark in the MemoryStore is highly bound by one of the joins in the query. I've created a cache which resolves this issue, you could give that a try since it will highlight performance changes with the pre-compilation to a much higher degree.

Caching implementation: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/3524

I noticed, that in this push I am not actually using the `ArrayBindingSet` at all. That means all the code is just being a bit difficult about getting to the same hashmap as before. I will just go and bang my head against my desk for a bit :(
Just jumping in to say that I'm massively impressed by the progress here. I'm still not able to spend as much time on RDF4J as I'd like but it looks like I'm not really needed. Great stuff everyone!

Looks really good :-) Especially distinctPredicates is much faster.

This does not yet include my work in the lmdb-lazy branch?

@kenwenzel no it doesn't include your latest work. It's mostly due to more compact ArrayBindingSet over the QueryBindingSet that performance umproves. Still that can be improved but requires a clearing  up of #3530 

I need to profile execution now and probably redo the unbound test. Also QueryBindingSet is still used in quite a few places. I'll open an issue on that next week.
A few new commits. But this no longer really affects the speed of the queries benchmarked. Important is a single fix for the regex compiled pattern logic.

We have some more query benchmarks if you want to see if there are any more differences. 

I would also appreciate if this PR was merged soon. I have some binding set improvements that I would like to contribute as a stop gap before you get index based binding sets working.

I will merge it Monday 10th of January 2022. I will fix the merge conflicts.
